Ottawa, November 7, 1930.

Gentlemen:

I have your letter of the 1st instant, relative to the recharges for the various Indian residential schools as mentioned therein.

In reply I have to request that you will arrange to ship, charges prepaid, the following number of recharges for Thermos extinguishers to each of the addresses as mentioned below:

9 Recharges - Rev. J. P. MacKay,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.,
and forward your account, in triplicate, with receipt for any charges prepaid, to Rev. Father MacKay.

9 Recharges - Mr. W. Dyers, Esq.,
Cecilin Jeffrey Indian Res. School,
Kenora, Ont.,
and forward your account, in triplicate, with receipt for any charges prepaid, to Frank Edwards, Esq., Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

6 Recharges - Rev. S. H. McVitty,
Mount Elgin Indian Res. School,
Muncey, Ont.,
and forward your account, in triplicate, with receipt for any charges prepaid, to Rev. Mr. McVitty.

9 Recharges - Rev. G. H. Haley,
Coxeetla Indian Res. School,
Hardie, B.C.,
and forward your account, in triplicate, with receipt for any charges prepaid, to Rev. Mr. Haley.

The above are being informed of the order placed with you, and requested, upon receipt of the recharges, to certify the accounts and send them to the Department, when payment will be made.

I may add that it is not the intention of the Department at the present time to order refills for the Thermos extinguishers supplied the following: 3 - G. H. Sims, Esq.,ault Ste. Marie, Ont., and 3 - Crosby Girls' Home, Port Simpson.

Your early attention to the above will oblige,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
F. N. Page

Pyrene Ref. Co. of Canada Ltd.,
1197-1207 King St. W.,
Toronto, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RC 10, Volume 6207, file 468-5, part 6)
Ottawa, November 8, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

In August, 1929, the Department supplied 6 Thermene fire extinguishers for the use of the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School. It is now necessary that new charges be placed in these extinguishers, and the Department is today placing an order with the Pyrene Mfg. Co. of Canada Ltd., Toronto, to forward, addressed to you, refills for 6 extinguishers of the Thermene type.

The above firm have been requested to forward their account to you in triplicate. When you receive the recharges, you should certify the account in the usual manner and forward it to the Department in duplicate, retaining one copy on file in your office.

You should see that these recharges are installed in the extinguishers and that the extinguishers are placed in good condition and ready for immediate use.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Rev. S. R. McVitty,
Principal,
Mount Elgin Indian Res. School,
Muncey, Ont.

CANADA
Mount Elgin Indian Residential School

McVITTY, Principal

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

November 25th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

There are a number of fences on the Institute Farm proper that are about twenty years old. Many posts have either broken off or have heaved out of the ground, wires are rusty and broken in many places beyond repair. We are not very busy these days and would gladly rebuild these fences if we had the wire and posts. I think that probably $150.00 would be sufficient to cover the cost. The work really needs to be done and owing to there being so much unemployment I think that the time is most opportune. We will also need a small grant for new belts for the machinery in our laundry. I think that probably $25.00 will be sufficient.

I am pleased to say that never has our attendance been as large as it is this year. The health and conduct of the pupils is excellent.

Hoping for an early authorization,

I am Dear Sir

Yours Respectfully

[Signature]

Principal.

Ottawa, December 1st, 1930.

Reverend Sir,

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, requesting authority to incur an expenditure of $150 in repairing the fences on the Institute Farm proper at the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School and, also, that a grant of $25 be provided to purchase new belts for the machinery in the laundry.

In connection with these requests, I have to say that our funds for the balance of the present fiscal year are entirely assigned. The cost of the labour and the material required in repairing the fences and in the purchase of new belts for the laundry machinery will, therefore, have to be provided from the per capita earnings or other receipts of the school, if necessary to incur the above expenditures at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. S. R. McVitty,
Principal,
Mount Elgin Indian Res. School,
Hancey, Ont.

February 7th, 1931.

To Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ontario.

Dear Sir,

I regret to report that on or about January 20th our large low pressure boiler sprang a leak. It was an emergency case on account of heating the main building so we had the manufacturers of the boiler send out a man to execute the necessary repairs.

We endorse his account herewith which we hope the Department will approve and pay.

We understand that the water grate tubes have served their usual time and will have to be replaced in the near future.

We expect a written report from the makers which on receipt we will forward to you.

I am dear sir,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal

August 19th, 1931.

Dear Sir:

In the matter of our requisition of the 6th Inst., and your reply of the 12th Inst., 7-0-5, would say that in making our requisition we had in mind the need of economy and cut everything to the lowest possible point. We can get along, in a way without the seats but the other things are absolutely necessary.

The furnace must have a pipe.

Electrical switches and wiring must be made safe.

The two Junior Rooms must be properly screened. Flies coming from outside toilets and stables are a menace.

The Farm House must have certain repairs to make it habitable, and lumber is absolutely necessary for repairs to steps, pupils' boxes, farm and stable doors etc., so there you are.

We are only asking £25.00 which in a school of this size is a mere bagatelle, less than is often spent on a little Day School on a Reserve.

We are economizing in every way consistent with efficiency. Our farming and live stock operations, once a source of revenue, are at present a bill of expense.

Our per capita grant is low compared with some other schools, and our Mission Board is as hard up as the Government, so I think our plan must be as follows.

1. The school will function as economically as possible.

2. In the event of a deficit in our current account we must look to the Mission Board for help; it is part of their contract.

3. In the matter of keeping buildings safe and sanitary we must look to the Department at least for the necessary material which is but a small part of the cost. We are undertaking to do even electrical repairs—a dollar per hour job if a city man were brought out here for the work.

4. Help us all you can—we will do the best we can. Send blackboard as soon as possible—we want to get it in position right away.

I am Dear Sir

Yours respectfully,

S. R. Mitty
Principal.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.

Dear Sir:

During the past seven years our water supply for all purposes has been secured by a small motor and pump driven by Hydro. Both failed us a few days ago. We had the manufacturers, The Empire Brass Co., send out a man; he found the motor quite used up and the pump needing certain repairs. We could not possibly get along without the water supply, so had a new motor installed and the pump repaired. The total cost will approximate $60.00. We would appreciate authorization of this very necessary expenditure.

The grates in the small hot water boiler that heats our Annex building need to be replaced before we can put on a fire, and as the cold weather is almost with us and our two junior class rooms are situated in that building we would appreciate an early authorization for this repair also.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa, October 21, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, relative to the need of a new motor and pump for use in connection with the water supply system at the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School. You may forward a certified voucher, in triplicate, covering the expenditure incurred for this purpose.

You may also arrange to have new grates installed in the small hot water boiler which heats the annex building. The cost for this purpose should be kept as low as possible, and you should forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Dear Sir:

One of the two washers in our laundry has been in use for many years and is now leaking so badly as to be unfit for use; it will fall to pieces someday. The need is great and "the sooner, the better" as we may be left stranded some of these days.

Hoping for a favorable reply,

I am dear sir,

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM T. ROY AULD, M.D., Medical Superintendent, Caradoc Agency, following his visit to LT. ELGIN INSTITUTE - letter dated January 18, 1934, addressed to Mr. Stone.

Original on 7-0-13.

I believe that certain recommendations are in order for the Institute worth of consideration. They are as follows:

The system of ventilation in the sleeping dormitories be improved. At present this is notoriously poor, particularly if there are many pupils ill. Dr. G. B. Strapp, assistant principal, and myself have repeatedly discussed the situation and if limited funds were available an electric motor and large fan for each dormitory would make conditions satisfactory.

The installation of modern bath equipment when and as finances will permit.

Provide a separate toilet (toilet to be used only by the dormitory) near the main building, either indoors or out for the girls with a attendant or caretaker and supervision at least once every night.

A bath house for boys and girls, connected to the main building, with a attendant or the oral effect to be determined.

Mr. J. D. Sutherland,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ontario.

Re: Repairs and Improvements -
Mount Elgin Residential School.

I have just returned from spending twenty-four hours at
Mount Elgin. For the first time I have gone carefully over the whole plant
and its equipment and am sending this letter to you - not because I wish
an immediate answer - but because I want you to have time to think over
the problem before I come to Ottawa on the 21st.

This is the third visit which I have made within six or
seven months, and I am taking the liberty of outlining two programmes.
The first contains what would be necessary in order to make the plant and
equipment worthy of the Government and the Church; the other, the barest
minimum of improvements which must be undertaken within the next year if
we are to carry on at all.

Ideally, then, the following things should be undertaken:

1st.- An extension to the present dining-room and assem-
bly room of about 20 feet. Under existing conditions, 150 children are
being fed in a basement dining-room which is hopelessly inadequate. Apart
from the hygienic reasons which indicate larger space, the present fearful
over-crowding makes any kind of training in table deportment absolutely
impossible. The assembly room, which is immediately above the dining-room,
and which was originally a class-room, is so small that it is practically
impossible to crowd the staff and the student body into it.

2nd.- The annex should be torn down, or failing that, com-
pletely rebuilt. My personal impression is that the foundation is slipping
and that an attempt to remodel the present building would be a very diffi-
cult proposition - if not utterly impossible.

The little children, who are now climbing rickety outside
stairs to their class-rooms, should be provided for in class-rooms on the
ground floor of the new building, and the senior class, which now meets in
the main building, should also be provided for there. That would release
the present senior class-room for a boys' reading and recreation room -
something which is very badly needed.

Upstairs there should be a gymnasium. This could also be
used as an assembly room when the students put on plays and demonstrations
to which their parents are invited.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6207, file 408-5, part 6)
Mr. J. D. Sutherland:

The basement of the new building should be a modern root cellar for the storage of vegetables.

3rd.— A new cottage for the herdsmen.— This would provide the farmer, the engineer and the herdsmen with homes a little off the school campus, as there are already two houses.

4th.— A small annex at each end of the building, running up the three floors, containing bathing and toilet facilities.

5th.— A new laundry.

If these changes were made, Mount Elgin would begin to approximate the type of building which is to be found at Brandon, Edmonton and Coqualeetsa.

The minimum repairs which must be attended to immediately are as follows:

1st.— A new septic tank.— No change has been made in this equipment since the original building was erected so far as I can find out. The water from the roof drains into it. The water from the sinks in the kitchen also drains into it. In a time of severe rains, the sewage backs up into both the boys' and the girls' playrooms and flushes through so rapidly that the proper bacteriological action is impossible, polluting the river which runs at the back of the school.

The drainage pipes have not been changed since 1895 and are so corroded that they are almost useless. Most of the tile in the drains outside is not modern and they are not cemented together.

2nd.— If the annex, containing bathing and toilet facilities, is beyond the realm of possibility, then there should be added immediately, in addition to the new drainage pipes, two stands and two toilets in each of the boys' dormitories, and at least five more toilets in the girls' dormitories.

3rd.— The washrooms on the ground floor need to be entirely rebuilt.

4th.— The only supply of hot water in the main building at the present time comes from a tank which is very little larger than the one which is installed in an ordinary eight-roomed house in this city and is heated by a small jacket heater which would be adequate for a family. A new tank and a new jacket heater, similar to the ones in Brandon and Coqualeetsa, should be installed in the engine-room, so that all the fires will be in the same place and outside of the main building.

5th.— The laundry should be rebuilt. It may be that an expert would agree that the old walls and roof are usable. If so, new floors and steel joists are certainly indicated. The present joists are so rotten that one can pick them to pieces with his hands, and we are lucky that the tre-
Mr. J. D. Sutherland,

mendons weight of the cement floor, which for some unknown reason was put down on the top of the original board floor, and the laundry machinery have not broken through into the cellar, precipitating pupils into scalding steam.

6th.— An annex to the laundry should be erected, with dressing-rooms upstairs and bathrooms downstairs.

New laundry tubs, in place of the old insanitary wooden ones which are now in the laundry, should be installed.

7th.— An automatic stoker and fan should be attached to the boiler which heats the main building. On Tuesday last, in every one of the class-rooms the teachers were using stoves. On the North side of the buildings particularly, this was necessary in order to keep the radiators from freezing. I think the radiation is insufficient—at least on the first two floors—but it might be that with the stoker and fan which I have just mentioned, a sufficiently uniform temperature could be maintained so as to obviate the use of stoves throughout the building. The cost of such an improvement in the furnace-room would be readily offset by the decreased fire hazard.

8th.— An adequate refrigerator of the walk-in type is very necessary and would add greatly—not only to the quality of the food supplied to the pupils—but to the efficiency of the kitchen staff.

There are many other small repairs and improvements necessary which can be cared for in the next fiscal year out of school revenue and need not be detailed here.

Dr. McLeod, the Department Health Officer at Lancey, was present the other day and we spent three or four hours discussing the situation. I have no doubt that he will be making a report to Dr. Stone in regard to the whole matter.

I wish it were possible for the Department to have someone from your Architect's Office visit Lancey before February 21st. Before anything is done I think we ought to have expert advice. We are fortunate in the fact that Mr. Strapp is an experienced mechanic who understands a good deal about the problems involved in building and equipping a school of this type. Any improvements which are to be undertaken can be carried out without expense so far as supervision is concerned. It is possible that a considerable part of the work can be done by the school staff.

I have dealt in this letter only with the complaints which Miss Webster made about the building and equipment. The questions which arise in connection with the programme of work and study and play need not be discussed by correspondence. In fact, I would not have written this letter were I not anxious that you should get from some other source at your command an accurate estimate of what is needed, and the possible cost. I am willing to send our Board architect to Lancey to go over the place, but I do not think...

that is the wise thing to do, as the Department would want advice from its own officers anyway.

Trusting that we may have a good deal of time to talk over this intricate problem soon,

Dear Sir;

In reply to your request to submit report on the condition of the school at Cowichan Bay, I may say that I have visited the school recently and have reviewed and inspected conditions at the school, and wish to submit the following report and recommendations:

1. Septic Tank: The present septic tank is inadequate for the needs of the school. Raw sewage from the roof drain flows into the tank and is not properly treated and allows raw sewage to enter the boy's playroom. The flood waters passing directly through the septic tank flush the raw sewage therefrom and carry it openly to the river polluting this stream. In addition, sink drainage goes to this tank and interferes with proper bacterial action.

A new septic tank is necessary with systems capable of collecting and treating water from roofs which is desired for the laundry and bath. The new septic tank is also necessary if any other facilities are installed.

2. Bathrooms: Toilets are required for each of the two boys dormitories (4 toilets) and 4 toilets in the girls dormitory and three flush toilets in the upper female dormitory. The present facilities are quite unsatisfactory and the conditions are so bad that they should be entirely replaced. In view of the weather conditions and possibility of an inspection of the new system, the present vault type are most undesirable and prone to failure.

3. Bathing Accommodation—A unit of ten modern baths is required for use of the pupils. If a new laundry were built these could be housed in the same structure. Present bathing facilities are inadequate. Bath bowls are also required in the boys' and girls' playrooms, and the cut-down type would be the most economical. These would serve the children prior to erecting their halls.

4. Laundry Building—During my visit of inspection the principal mentioned an addition to the present laundry building. The roof of this building, which is really several feet above the floor, is made of corrugated iron as heavy as ever, is of brick over which concrete has been mixed. In the rear of this is a raised platform used as a storage place for water and a number of other things. The condition of the walls is very poor, due to vibration, caused in part by the persons working thereon and in part by the fact that the air is so dense inside the building. This is not a healthy habit, and I believe it should be remedied. As I said, I am not sure of this from all angles, and I believe aware of the worst needs of this situation. It might be feasible to renew this roof, but I am of the opinion that a second story is indicated in view of the fact that but little provision can be provided in the present structure. If such a change is to occur the question of heating the laundry is an important one, and should be considered at this juncture.

April 9, 1934.

Memorandum

Doctor McGill,

I beg to report that on April 4th I made an inspection of the Mount Elgin Institute at Muncey, and I am now preparing a report covering this inspection. In the meantime, however, owing to the urgency of the situation I think it advisable to give you particulars about the laundry building.

This building was erected by the Church authorities some forty years ago. It is a solid brick building, approximately 40 x 26, consisting of basement, ground and first floor. The portion used for a laundry is the ground floor. This floor is constructed with wood joists and a wooden floor, and some time during the past years a concrete floor was laid over the top of the wooden floor. All the laundry machinery, which consists of two large washers, an extractor, and two flat work ironers, are located on this floor. There is also on the ground floor a high pressure steam boiler for supplying steam to the washers and ironers, and a gas engine used as power for operating the laundry machinery. On this floor also are located old wooden laundry tubs, which are not used for laundry purposes but for bathing the pupils.

The joints supporting the ground floor are badly rotted where they rest on their supports, and there is great danger that the floor will collapse at any time, as it is not strong enough to carry the laundry machinery, especially during the time they are operating the laundry machinery which sets up a very strong vibration.

The ironers and washers are supplied with steam at high pressure from the steam boiler, and in the case of the floor collapsing the building would be filled with steam. I would strongly recommend that arrangements be made immediately to put this building in proper shape for laundry purposes, and that the present ground floor be taken out, the basement which is not used be filled in and a new concrete floor installed.
Doctor McGill,

The interior would require to have the walls plastered and a motor driven fan installed for ventilation.

It would also be necessary to install a drying tumbler and three new laundry tubs to take the place of the old battery of fifteen wooden tubs.

The Principal has offered to do as much of the work as possible with his Staff, providing the department will supply the material and one or two expert mechanics. The estimated cost of the changes above mentioned would be approximately $1,800.00.

I may say that if these changes are not carried out immediately it will be necessary to instruct the School to close the laundry as there is great danger of loss of life if operated under present conditions.

When the old laundry tubs, which are the only means at present for the bathing of the children, are removed provision will have to be made in the main building for these facilities, and I will include this in my general report on the building.

April 13, 1924.

Memorandum

Doctor McGill,

I beg to report that in accordance with your instructions I made an inspection of the Mount Elgin Institute at Nansoy on Wednesday, April 4th.

The Mount Elgin Institute was founded by the Methodist Church in 1861. The original building was erected in this year and enlarged in 1868. A new wing was added in 1875, and in 1912 an addition 40 feet long was added to each end of the building. Since 1912 practically no improvements have been carried out to the main building with the exception of some minor repairs and alterations to that portion of the building occupied by the Principal and the Staff.

In a letter received from the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada they outlined a list of improvements, which in their opinion, should be undertaken. These are as follows:

1. An extension to the present pupils' dining room and the assembly hall which is located above the dining room.
2. The annex, which is part of the original school erected in 1861, be either torn down or rebuilt.
3. A new cottage for the headmaster.
4. An addition on each end of the building running up three floors to contain bathing and toilet facilities.
5. A new laundry building.
6. A new septic tank.
7. The installing of the necessary equipment to provide for an adequate supply of hot water.
8. An automatic stoker for the boiler.
9. A suitable cold storage room in the basement.

When making my inspection of the building I paid particular attention to the above requests, and I would respectfully submit the following recommendations:

1. I do not consider it necessary to provide an extension to the building in order to increase the accommodation in the dining room and assembly hall. This extra accommodation can be provided in the building, if a rearrangement is made of the rooms on the basement, ground floor, and first floor. At the present time there is entirely too much space occupied by staff rooms. This space can be considerably reduced to provide the additional space needed for the pupils. As an example of the excessive space occupied by the Staff I may say that the Reverend Principal has a sitting room 15 x 15 - a parlour 10 x 15 - a private dining room 20 x 15 - four bedrooms 14 x 15, and there is also a staff dining room 20 x 15 and a kitchen 20 x 15.
This accommodation is far in excess of what is required and provided for in our newer Residential Schools. To my mind it is not necessary or advisable that the Staff dining rooms be supplied from a separate kitchen. There is no reason why all the cooking for the Institute should not be done in the same kitchen as this system is followed with success in our other Residential Schools.

2. With reference to the annex this building is in a fair state of repair, with the exception of the South wall. This wall has settled considerably, and it will be necessary to have it shored up and a new foundation provided.

The annex is used to provide accommodation for two married members of the Staff and two classrooms. The present layout of rooms is far from satisfactory, as the classrooms are located on the first floor and the living quarters of the annex is by an outside stairway and drain leading from the ground. One classroom is at one end of the building and the other at the other. I would recommend that the rooms be re-arranged to provide both classrooms at one end of the building, and an inside staircase built to provide access to the classrooms.

3. With reference to the request for a cottage for the herdsman, there is a cottage on the property at the present time, which could be used for this purpose, but it is occupied by Mr. Caple who vacated his house in the village for the use of the Doctor. Since a Doctor's residence is built at Runcy Mr. Caple will move into his own house and the cottage will then be available for the herdsman. I may say that the above arrangement was the best that could be made to provide living quarters for the Doctor. There are no other houses available in Runcy.

4. With reference to the addition for toilets, etc., I consider that there is ample space in the building to provide for toilet and bathing facilities. At the present time the school is deficient in sanitary appliances in every department except the portion occupied by the Staff. There are no tub baths in the school for the bathing of the pupils, and at present they are bathed once a week in the old wooden laundry tub in the laundry.

The only closets available to the pupils in the school are night toilets located in the dormitories. During the day it is necessary for them to use outside closets which are located a considerable distance from the school, and at present are in a very unsanitary condition.

There is ample space in the rooms adjoining the recreation rooms on the Boys' and Girls' sides of the building in which to install proper sanitary conveniences, and I would recommend that these rooms be fitted up with tub baths, shower baths and closets.

5. A new laundry building is not necessary. I have already submitted to you a report and recommendations with regard to the old laundry.

6. A new septic tank and drainage system does not appear of any great urgency at the present time. The only trouble experienced with the working of the system is during high water in the spring and heavy rains in the summer. It would appear that the drain pipe leading from the septic tank is not large enough. The only way to
ascertain the condition of the present tank and drainage system would be to have the same uncovered for inspection.

7. Regarding the installation of a hot water system it will be necessary to provide an adequate supply of hot water when the heating facilities have been provided. I would recommend that a thousand gallon tank be installed together with a jacket heater. The most efficient and satisfactory way to operate the jacket heater would be to provide a blower with automatic control.

8. An automatic stoker for the boiler would no doubt be of great assistance to the school in operating their heating system. The installation however is rather expensive and I do not think that it should be considered at the present time. Now that electric power is available at the school it would be more desirable to install in place of the gravity furnace to the boiler a receiving tank and pump. This would provide for the circulation of the hot water throughout the building, and would make it much easier to heat the rooms that are located at the greatest distance from the boiler room.

9. A cold storage room is needed. This is being provided for in all our new Residential Schools, and it is practically impossible to keep the school supplies of food in proper condition without it.

I would recommend that proper bathing and toilet facilities for the pupils be provided, including the installation of a new hot water system. Also as recommended in my memorandum of the 4th instant that the necessary repairs be made to the laundry building. These two items to my mind are the most important and urgent at the present time. The estimated cost of providing the baths, closets and hot water system would be approximately $2,000, and as before mentioned in my memorandum of the 4th the cost of the repairs to the laundry would be approximately $1,500, making a total of $3,500. It will be necessary this year to provide a new foundation for the south end of the annex. This will cost approximately $200.00 and if possible the interior should be rearranged as outlined, which would cost approximately $500.00.

The Reverend Principal has offered to do as much of the work as possible with the members of the Staff provided the department will pay for the materials and any expert labour required.

With reference to the rearrangement of the rooms to provide additional accommodation for the pupils' dining room, cold storage room, etc., it will be necessary to propose a plan of the basement, ground floor and second floors of the building so that such rearrangements could be made of the rooms to take the best advantage of the space available. I may say that at present the kitchen is very poorly located, with practically no light or ventilation, and it will have to be placed in some other portion of the building. I might also mention that the building is so badly out of shape that there are six different flights of stairs leading from the ground floor, whereas under proper planning two only would be required.

It will cost approximately $20,000 to put this building in proper shape to provide accommodation similar to that in our new Residential Schools. It will not be necessary to make any additions to the present building, but a rearrangement of the interior. If funds...
can be provided this year for the laundry and sanitary conveniences, as above mentioned, next year it might be possible to make a start on rearranging the rooms. This work could be spread over several years, but in the interests of economy and satisfactory results a definite plan must be decided upon before any alterations are undertaken.

Memorandum: Dear Mr. McGill,

I beg to report that on May 4th and 5th of last week I visited the Mount Elgin Institute at Munsey, and made arrangements for commencing the work of remodelling the old laundry building.

In accordance with instructions I interviewed Mr. H. W. Wrightman. He was anxious to act as foreman on the work, but I was unable to employ him as he lacked the necessary qualifications and experience. I may say that Mr. Wrightman is a farmer located a few miles from the village of Munsey, and has had practically no experience in building construction except that obtained in working around his own farm buildings. He promised, however, to arrange for a competent foreman.

On Saturday morning Mr. Wrightman met Mr. H. H. Bellamy, a builder from Mount Bridges to take charge of the work. In going over the proposed alterations and additions with Mr. Bellamy I found that he was well equipped to take charge, and arrangements were made to commence the alterations on Tuesday morning of this week. I gave Mr. Bellamy instructions to give as much employment as possible in the unskilled labour to deserving Indians and to obtain from the Indian Agent the names of those to be employed.

The Canadian "Drytex" Tumbler
Motor Drive—Non-reversing—Laundry Type

The American Drytex Tumbler quoted shall be (steam), (gas), (electric) heated, motor driven, with a cylinder thirty-six (36) inches in diameter by . . . . inches in length, and shall have vertical partitions, and . . . . compartments.

Cylinder
Shall be constructed of 31/4 mesh, .080-inch galvanized woven wire, rolled after being woven, so that the intersections are interlocked. Cylinder heads shall be of spun galvanized-iron. Woven wire mesh shall be held to cylinder heads by galvanized-iron bands riveted to the heads. Trunnions shall be bolted to cylinder heads. Four 4-inch metal ribs shall be riveted to the woven wire and cylinder heads.

The galvanized-iron cylinder door shall be of the hinged type, with embossed perforations. Door shall have two latches. A hook shall be provided to hold the cylinder door in the open position. A galvanized reinforcing rib shall be riveted and soldered to the door sheet between the latches.

Frame
The upper part shall be of cast-iron, lined with galvanized-iron, and arranged so that each end frame can be taken apart at the cylinder bearings. The lower portion shall be of welded steel angles, forming supports for the fan bearings and motor. The upper portion of the frames shall support the housing for the heating units and driving mechanism.

Housing
The outer shell or housing shall be constructed of galvanized-iron, rigidly attached to the upper and lower frame sections. Shall be of close fitting construction, to prevent leakage of air and heat.

HEATING UNITS

Steam
The heating unit shall be located in a galvanized-iron housing at the upper rear of the Tumbler. The heater shall be of the fin type, of ample capacity to insure proper heating of the Tumbler. The air shall enter the heater housing through the screened top. The heated air shall be drawn through the work being tumbled by means of a fan located below the cylinder.
The Canadian 'Drytex" Tumbler—Continued
Motor Drive—Non-reversing—Laundry Type

Gas
The heating unit shall be located in a galvanized-iron housing at the upper rear of the Tumbler. A pilot light shall be provided. A baffle plate shall be arranged to prevent the air coming into the heater chamber from passing over the open gas flame. The gas burners shall be adjustable for various degrees of heat. Heater shall be of ample capacity to insure proper heating of the Tumbler. The air shall enter the heater housing through the screened top. The heated air shall be drawn through the work being tumbled by means of a fan located below the cylinder.

Electric
The heating elements shall be located in a galvanized-iron housing at the upper rear of the Tumbler. The heater shall be of ample capacity to insure proper heating of the Tumbler. The heater shall be energized through a magnetic switch closed by closing the shell door, and interlocked so that the fan must be running while the heater is on. The air shall enter the heater housing through the screened top. The heated air shall be drawn through the work being tumbled by means of a fan located below the cylinder.

Fans
There shall be one fan on the 36x30" machine, and two on the 36x48" machine. Each fan shall consist of two cast-aluminum paddle-wheel type fans, placed back to back in a galvanized-iron housing. Galvanized-iron clutches shall connect the fan housings to the shell. The moisture laden air shall be exhausted through a horizontal duct at the rear of the Tumbler near the floor. The fans shall be mounted on a through shaft, "V" belt driven.

Bearings
The cylinder bearings shall be of the self-aligning ball bearing type. The intermediate bearing shall be plain. The fan bearings shall be ball bearing.

Brake
Shall be of the manually operated type, located on the left-hand end of the Tumbler. The brake lever shall be so arranged that the opening of the case door will actuate the lever, stop the motor, and apply the brake.

Belt Guards
All driving mechanism shall be enclosed in sheet metal guards, to comply with the safety codes.

Cylinder Door Spotting Device
The Tumbler shall be provided with power operated means for bringing the cylinder door into alignment with the shell door. The device shall be controlled by the brake lever.

Motor
Shall be of the single shaft extension, ball bearing, grease lubricated type. Shall be of ample capacity and proper speed to insure quiet running, guaranteed to meet operating characteristics of the machine, and shall be mounted integral with the machine, driving same through "V" belts. Both direct and alternating current motors shall be of the horizontal type, insulated to withstand heat and dampness incidental to laundry machinery.

Wiring
Shall be furnished in conduit, with proper terminals provided for line connections.

Lubrication
All important bearings shall be provided with grease gun fittings.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Regarding your request of the 23rd to have one of our Company go to the Mount Elgin Institute, Muncey, to check over the Laundry Equipment there, we are pleased to advise that the writer had the pleasure of personally taking care of this matter and on May 30th, in the afternoon, met the Institute Superintendent, Rev. Mr. Stroppe, at London and he very kindly drove me to Muncey and under his direction with a crew of men we immediately got busy in bringing the machinery from the outside of the building and lining it up in its proper position in the laundry room.

Commencing with the power pump which was set in the corner near the woodshed, we followed this machine with the extractor, then the Toronto metal washer and finally the Canadian Laundry Machinery wood washer, allowing sufficient room for working space and piping, etc., that is connected to the machine.

There was provided space sufficient to take care of the wood tubs which would follow the washer line and placed in close proximity to the boiler room door leading from the laundry.

The engine was placed on the foundations provided for it and after this we followed up the placing of the 66" #6111 Steam Heated Flatwork Ironer, Canadian Laundry Machinery make, in a line with the pipe columns in the center of the laundry room and followed this up by the placing of the 75" Tierney Type, Flatwork Ironer, of the York Manufacturing Company.

We then sized up the pulleys to get the correct drive and speed and it will be necessary to provide a new small wooden pulley for the Canadian Flatwork Ironer.

The machinery as positioned leaves good room and working space for the contemplated new drying tumbler which will set at right angles to the washer and extractor line back up against the wall at the woodshed partition and the exhaust from this machine can be piped into the woodshed, or if desired, to the chimney connection in the wall. Personally, I believe piping it to the woodshed will be much more satisfactory as there will be less flue connections for the fans to work against but in either case would recommend a
turnkey in the exhaust pipe so that it can be closed in the wintertime so that
the cold air cannot get down to the coils and freeze up same.

The layout of the machinery lends itself to efficient operation. The soiled
linen can come into the laundry and be placed in the corner by the stairway,
from which the person operating the washers can obtain a supply of soiled
linen to wash. It will then follow in the natural sequence from the washer
to the extractor, from the extractor to the drying tumbler, where it will be
shaken out, if the articles are needed, to be fully dried, and those to be
ironed partially dried, and from this machine on through the flatwork ironer,
then folded and placed on the tables which would be provided along the wall
at the delivery side of the flatwork ironers.

Rev. Mr. Stroppe and myself afterwards went over the entire laundry equipment
for the purpose of determining what repairs would be necessary.

The washers are in good working condition. There is a slight movement in the
bore of the loose pulleys but not sufficient to warrant rebushing. The balance
of the machines seem to be in serviceable working order.

The extractor appears to be in good shape with one exception, that the small
bracket which supports the spring and rod which keeps the brake away from the
pulley is broken and should be welded. Otherwise the machine is in good work-
ing order.

The Canadian flatwork ironer we checked over and found correct with the excep-
tion of the cast iron rod which supports the weight that functions with the
automatic stop is broken. This can be welded and should be before the machine
is put into operation. Otherwise, the automatic stop is not kept in its
correct position to function properly if needed.

The York flatwork ironer of Tierney type is terribly old but shows care and in-
genuity on the part of those that have cared and maintained the machine at
the Institute and have kept it running. The stuffing box gland and nut at the
point of steam entry is showing excessive wear on the thread of the bronze nut.
We believe in a short time it will be necessary for you to have a new one made
locally at London, where the present nut can be used as a pattern and new
thread cut of the same thread per inch but several thousandths smaller as there
is some wear on the cast iron gland that this nut fits on. Considerable dif-
ficulty is experienced in keeping this steam tight and if you have this nut
made probably the Empire Brass Company of London, Ontario, could do this work
for you very conveniently.

One of the pinions on the roll of this machine has badly worn teeth and two
of the teeth are only existing in part and we consider it necessary to replace
those that are broken off by small metal studs that could be drilled and tapped
into the cast iron pinion and this would enable the machine to function in a
more efficient condition than it is at present as it is quite possible that
the balance of the teeth will break off at any time unless the above remedy
is applied. Otherwise the machine is in working order and we must say that
the safety features that have been applied by the Rev. Mr. Stroppe are extreme-
ly well applied and guarantee a considerable measure of safety to the operators.

That about completes the list of repairs necessary as far as we could determine
and as they are of a nature that can be handled locally we hesitate to suggest
sending a mechanic from Toronto and incurring such expense to you. This I
fully believe, Rev. Mr. Stroppe agrees with as with the above repairs taken
Mr. R. Guernsey Orr,

care of your machinery would be in good working order.

We would like to suggest that you provide steam traps on both flatwork ironers and also the new drying tumbler which you contemplate purchasing. These will provide proper temperature in the machines and maintain it more consistently than with valves, even though you have no means at present of returning this waste condensation to the boiler.

We believe this is about the sum total of the report that we can make to you and want to assure you it has been a pleasure of having been of service to you, your Department and to the Institute. Very glad also to inform you that this service is no charge and we want to take this opportunity of thanking, through you, Rev. Mr. Stroppe who so kindly met me at London and drove me to the Institute and back.

Yours very truly,

The Canadian Laundry Machinery Co., Limited.

Sir;—

Attention Mr. Gurney Orr.

I would beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 12th containing the information that Mr. Skinner would visit Mount Elgin Institute and would advise that he did arrive this A.M. and is at present at the school.

Enclosed please find Labour Returns for wages paid to the amount of $560.95 for the weeks June 23rd to July 14th inclusive and which leaves me with the sum of $35.85 still on hand and I would request that another advance of $500.00 be sent forward at once.

I doubt that Mr. Skinner will be able to give a full report to you within a few days concerning the work at the school which has reached the point where more funds will have to be provided or the work left half finished. It will take all available funds now appropriated to complete the new class-rooms and living quarters without touching the existing class-rooms or the new bathing facilities in the old building. In fact I question if the funds still available will be enough to do that, as in remodeling many difficulties are encountered that are not at first known or when the work is completed.

The advance asked for should be sent forward as soon as possible.

Sept. 25, 1931.

Mr. Duskard,

With reference to your memorandum of the 19th instant, regarding repairs to the slate roof of one of the schools at Nuneys, I would say that the school referred to is the Mount Logan Indian Residential School. The Department has incurred expenditures this past summer in carrying out repairs and alterations to the main building and in providing laundry machinery to the amount of approximately $6,000.

The local Indian Agent reports that there are a number of the slate shingles on the roof either broken or missing and that the roof is lacking in several places. He estimates that it would require 400 slate shingles at $0.75 each to make the repairs required. He states that if the slate shingles are furnished, the school authorities would perform the labour, without cost to the Department.

I should be pleased to have the name of your correspondent, in order that he can be given an opportunity to quote on the supplying of the slate required, or the names of any other parties from whom quotations should be received. I may add that there are no funds specially provided for this purpose in our Appropriation for Indian Education.

November 20th, 1934,

Dear Sir:

I beg to respectfully draw your attention to a matter that, with the onset of cold weather, daily becomes more acute, namely, provision of hot water for the pupils' wash rooms. At the present time we have a small jacket heater with a storage tank of approximately 90 gallons capacity. This of course would provide plenty of hot water for perhaps fifteen persons but is hopelessly inadequate for one hundred and fifty.

During the last few months I have made a careful study of various systems of heating water for domestic use and have arrived at the conclusion that for our purpose a 'Flueless Upright Boiler' similar to the enclosed cut and specifications would prove to be the most satisfactory. This boiler could be installed in our present boiler room and connected with the supply lines with very little trouble. Not only would this supply sufficient hot water for the wash rooms but it would also be possible to set up the baths in the Main Building instead of using the Laundry Building, which under present conditions we are forced to do.

It will be noted that the price quoted is F.O.B. Factory. In order to save expense as far as possible the School will arrange for transportation and installation.

I trust that the Department will give this matter favorable consideration and authorize purchase and installation as soon as possible.

I remain

Yours respectfully,

Sir;-

I would beg to enclose my report for an inspection visit I made to the Mount Elgin Residential School on the 17th day of December, 1934.

Conditions at the school in so far as the welfare of the pupils are concerned, are in a very efficient state and while the children get eggs supplied them through puddings, they do not receive any for their breakfasts. I also think that they could do with a little more soup made from fresh meats and also have meat a little oftener for their dinner meal, as they were having no meat at all for the meal I attended. The Rev. principal stated to me that they receive meat four meals a week.

The barns at this school need painting badly to preserve them as they are getting badly rusted. This applies to the exterior wood-work of the whole school which needs painting badly. Mr. Strapp claims that at present there is no toilet fit for use in the boys' dormitory and that during the night they must go out. This he claims is caused by the corrosion of the pipes and a complete overhauling of them would have to be done before they could be used, and these repairs should be done at an early date as possible.

Sir;-

I would beg to enclose accounts in favour of Pennington Bros., Parkhill, Ont. for $158.00 and being for repairs made to the roof of the Mount Elgin School, which was authorized by your letter 7-05 of October 24-34.

To comply with the request in your letter I did obtain tenders from the two parties listed in your letter and which tenders are enclosed and that of Pennington Bros being the lowest was accepted. Believing that the tender of Pennington Bros was a very close estimate of the work needed and not wishing to have a re-action after the work was started I did phone Mr. Pennington to view the work and make sure that he could do a satisfactory job at his price and he sent a man down who did look over the job and was satisfied to do the complete job for $158.00 and I instructed him to go ahead with the work. The work was done during the time I was on vacation and was supervised by the Rev. Principal of the school.

After returning from my vacation I did receive the accounts for the work done and was going to forward them to the Department for payment on December 3rd, on which day the Principal of the school phoned me that the roof was again leaking in three places and I held up the accounts and phoned Pennington Bros to this effect and advised them to return and finish the job properly. They did not come and on December 8th I sent them a letter advising them of the leaks. They have this day appeared and claim that they have lost money on the job and it is not their fault that the roof is still leaking and they maintain that they besides other work done have put 550 slates on the roof, which they value at 40¢ a slate and desire an additional $10.00 to make the repairs still needed.
In repairing a slate roof it is nearly impossible to give a close estimate of the cost of such repairs and this work far exceeded the tender of Pennington Bros., who are to blame and I even gave them a chance to look over the work the second time before I instructed them to go ahead.

The Rev. O. B. Strapp informs me that the work that is at present needed to complete the job properly is a part of that which was contracted for and such being the case the firm should complete their work, no matter how much they are going to lose on their tender and which they now estimate as being between $8.00 and $10.00. Mr. Pennington also has informed me that he is taking this matter up with the Department through Mr. Campbell of Garwood and explaining his case. The account goes forward for whatever action the department desires to take.

As the actual cost for material would not exceed about $4.00 to buy flashing for the three leaks and as the slates are now all in good shape, I would suggest that this sum be authorized and that Mr. Strapp get one of his men at the school to do the work, for the main part of the Pennington estimate is for time from Parkhill to Mimico and labour.

Secretary,
Dept of Ind. Affs.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I take the liberty to acknowledge receipt of your letter of March 6th, dealing with the claim of Penrith Bros., Parkhill, Ont., for additional pay for the work they did on the slate roof of the Mount Elgin School and in excess of the $185.00 that was paid them in accordance with their tender. I would advise that I did write this firm on March 11th asking them for an itemized account of the material and labor they supplied and have just received their account on the 29th of March.

As previously stated by me I do believe the tender of this firm was low and they did lose money, but they were also given the second opportunity to adjust their tender and were satisfied to let it stand. At the time of looking over the work this firm did inform me that they would put on the slate shingles at 40¢ each if only a few were needed, but if a large quantity were needed they would do the work at 35¢ a shingle laid on.

Concerning the Reverend Principal of the School, Mr. Strapp informs me that no copper for gutters was supplied at all and that they were repaired by coating them with black asphalt paint. Mr. Strapp also states that after they had completed their work there were still three small leaks in the roof and the staff of the school had to complete this work. Taking the whole situation into consideration I would consider this firm would be well paid for their total work at the sum of $213.00 and would recommend accordingly.

In reaching this figure I would allow payment as follows: 550 slate shingles 11" x 33" laid down @ 35¢ each = $192.50; Labour for gutters, etc. @ $1.00; nails, tar, etc. @ $.50; Nails used @ $3.50; Flashing material @ $1.50; making a total of $213.00.
A consideration also in reaching the figure of $213.00 is the fact that I know of a firm in London that does roof repairing and upon inquiry they informed me that they were prepared to place shingles of this size on a roof at 30¢ a slate and if it was a large job they would consider a price of 25¢ a shingle laid down.

Enclosed please find a voucher in which I have made out for the full amount of $89.00 claimed by Pennington Bros., but which I only recommend payment to the amount of $75.00 to make the total of $213.00 I would allow.

Secretary,
Dept of Ind. Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. [Signature]

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

I have no doubt that you will have learned before this that none of the pupils of this School had left when the outbreak of measles, referred to in my recent telegram, occurred. I do not know just why, but this School has for years followed the practice of carrying on until the middle of July and then opening on September 1st. The Principal and his staff had, of course, immediately resorted to a re-arrangement of dormitory space as an emergency measure. It must be quite evident to anyone who knows the building that that inevitably means over-crowding some of the other dormitories in order to provide isolation for the pupils who are ill. In the event of fire or panic through some other cause, the fact that 150 pupils were attempting to use exits intended for 100 might easily result in loss of life or injury to some of the pupils. We feel that by reporting the matter and asking for immediate action, we have cleared ourselves of responsibility.

The whole situation is exceedingly unfortunate, as it breaks up the arrangements for staff holidays. I hope that long before this Mr. Orr has been able to visit Muncey and make some arrangements for beginning the improvements and alterations. I certainly do not intend the $20,000 in the Estimates for that purpose to be transferred to some other account, if I can help it.

Thanking you for your help in this important matter,

I am

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

Dear Dr. McGill: I beg to call your attention to the condition of the heating plants at this school.

The main building is heated by a "Low Pressure" boiler but owing to the general condition of the plant and the length of the leads it is not possible to keep the building at an even temperature. Mr. Orr of your department gave a definite promise over a year ago that he would arrange for an expert to make a survey of the plant and have it placed in proper order. NOTHING HAS BEEN DONE. I took the matter up with him on the occasion of his visit a few days ago and pressed for some action. Without doubt, as he admitted, our plant is not at all adequate. There should be two boilers of approximately two thirds the necessary capacity and the main building and the annex should be heated from a central plant. If that is not possible at present owing to the lack of funds for the purpose I beg to make the following recommendations:

1. A competent heating specialist be employed to overhaul the radiator steam traps, leads and insulation, and put same in good repair.

2. That an automatic stoker similar to that in operation at the Mohawk Institute at Brantford be installed.

The annex building, in which are located classrooms and bedrooms for members of the staff, is heated by a hot water jacket heater. Several of the radiator leads are now overloaded and there is yet another classroom to be heated. We were compelled to put stoves in the classrooms last year as it was not possible to use them at all without. I therefore make the following recommendation:

1. That the cellar be deepened so that the jacket heater may be set lower and permit proper rise for the hot lines to the radiators and fall for the returns.

2. That another heater similar to the present one be installed as an auxiliary to the present one and the load divided.

The cold weather is rapidly approaching and I am very anxious to have this matter attended to so that the pupils and staff may be at least reasonably comfortable this year.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir:

The following is a report on the present heating system in the above building. We received a request from Mr. Orr to investigate the cause of trouble with the heating:

PRESENT SYSTEM.

The present system is a Dunham return heating system with 22 radiators and a No. 11 return trap supplied by a 60° x 12'-6" Leonard downdraft firebox boiler. The system was not operating at the time the writer was on the job. However, the heating must be very unsatisfactory since some of the class rooms had stoves installed in addition to the radiators.

The Principal, Mr. Strapp informed me that the diaphragms had been removed from a large proportion of the radiator traps and that the steam escaped from the packless radiator valves, also that in cold weather the normal operating pressure was from 10 - 15 pounds. Several of the radiators are reported to be leaking.

The main piping and risers appear to be in good condition, and generally speaking the job is well installed although there are some locations where the grade could stand some adjustment.

The class room annex which is located about 30 ft. from the boiler room is heated by a hot water system and according to Mr. Strapp, this is also unsatisfactory, and they require additional stoves in the class rooms to obtain livable temperature conditions.
The present domestic hot water heating system is apparently unsatisfactory and should be replaced with more efficient equipment.

COMMENDATIONS:

The present heating system is a little too large to operate most efficiently as a gravity system and since the diaphragms in the traps and packless valves are obviously in need of replacement, we recommend that they be replaced with Differential tops and discs, and that a vacuum pump and regulating valves be installed to make a complete Dunham Differential Heating System. The control might be either manual or automatic but we suggest automatic control with the thermostat located in the Principal's apartment.

We further suggest that the Annex Building be heated from the main building with a new steam heating system, since the present heating system is unsatisfactory and the change would certainly save fuel.

In our opinion the domestic hot water for the laundry and buildings should be heated from the steam boiler and perhaps most satisfactorily by a heater below the boiler water line.

We have not been able to check the capacity of the present boiler to adequately handle the proposed load but it does not appear to be a very difficult job to extend the present boiler-room in order to install a stoker fired additional boiler, if necessary.

The present heating system could be easily arranged for gravity operation in case of interruptions in the supply of electricity to the building.

We hope this report may be of some assistance to Mr. Orr and we will be glad to cooperate further.

Yours very truly,
C. A. DUNHAM CO., LIMITED

Dear Sir,

I am working at Mount Elgin Institute at present, remodeling one of the Class Rooms, and notice there is a lot of work that should be done now before it gets worse, and takes a larger amount of money to repair. I feel sure if the matter was brought to your notice you would agree that if repairs were checked over & the most needed work done at the time it should be, it would save money & time & keep the buildings always in good repair. A good Carpenter could look after 2 or 3 different Institutes. By that I mean spend a month or longer at each one doing what was really necessary, and by that way there...
would be no need of spending any great amount of money outside of a few nails and a little lumber each year. As you know if a building is kept in good repair it takes very little, but if it is let go a few years it takes a much larger sum to repair it. If these suggestions are favorable to you & you should decide to give it a trial I would appreciate it. If you would give me a chance to work under your Department I can assure you of good work being done all the time and a big saving to the Department of Indian Affairs.

MUNCEY HOSPITAL PROPOSED; MENTAL WARDS OVERTAXED

Middlesex Grand Jury Makes Recommendation; Also Reports Ontario Hospital At London Is "Crowded Beyond Capacity"

Recommending construction of an emergency hospital for the Mount Hope Institute at the Muncey Indian Reserve and reporting that the Ontario Hospital here was "crowded beyond capacity," the grand jury made its presentation at the spring session held yesterday afternoon after making an inspection of public institutions in London and Middlesex County.

It was the first grand jury report to see the Muncey Indian Institute as a residential school for Indians.

In receiving the report Justice Kingstone spoke of the excellent examination made by the jurors. "Your report shows that you did not fail of hard work," declared his lordship. "You took trouble and pains to see that those institutions were properly run."

The report which was read to the court by Edwin Smith, secretary for the grand jury, was as follows:

"We desire to express our thanks to your lordship for the very clear and comprehensive explanation of our power and duties as grand jurors.

"On Wednesday afternoon, March 13th, we visited the Mt. Hope Indian residential school on the Muncey Reserve. This was the first visit by any grand jury to such institution. This school, but many years ago, closed but reopened in 1867, occupies a tract of land consisting of 200 acres and with a further rental of 50 acres. We were introduced to the principal, Rev. D. B. Strapp, by Dr. J. W. Strapp, resident physician at the Indian agent Mr. A. D. Muncey. This school became a centre for industrial and dairy work. There are 30 girls and 10 boys aged from 11 to 19 years. We credit it to the Federal Government's management as an institution of this nature. We would recommend that the department of Indian affairs at Ottawa be requested to supply this institution with adequate accommodation also an emergency hospital capable of taking care of both sexes, with accommodation for six or eight patients. The heating system is at present inefficient, and could be improved at least 30 per cent in the installation of a vacuum pump or air eliminator on the return line."

Dear Mr. Orr:

Res: Arrangements for Chapel,
Mount Elgin Indian Residential School

Following our conversation with you the other day, Mr. Strapp and I have been making some investigations as to the probable cost of fitting up as a chapel the large room, now used as an assembly room and furnished with double school desks. The delay has been caused by the anxiety of the Dennisteel Corporation Ltd., to make sure that the iron beam for which we asked would carry the weight, in place of the pillars which now run, as you will remember, right down through the centre of the room. They have finally concluded that an ordinary trussed floor beam is impracticable, but that an "I" beam is strong enough to carry the load and to be perfectly safe.

I am enclosing the rough sketch which Mr. Strapp has made to indicate how the room would be arranged. You will notice that practically all of the expenditure is for equipment which can be transferred to the chapel in a new school when it is erected.

The items are as follows:

- Supplying and placing in position the "I" beam: $65.00
- 175 seats @ $2.00 each: $350.00
- 90 hymnbook racks @ 40 cents each: $36.00
- Pulpit: $45.00
- Lectern: $60.00 (less 20%)
- Altar: $60.00
- Two platform chairs: $20.00

(Sales tax on all of the above extra)

- Electrical fixtures and repairs: $25.00
- Material for rebuilding platform: $25.00
- 10 gals. Paint @ $2.70: $27.00

All the labor, except what is necessary to install the "I" beam and the ventilating fans - that is all the unskilled labor - would be supplied by the School, without cost.

For your information, we are also enclosing clippings from the catalogue of the Valley City Seating Company, indicating the type of fixtures which are included in the estimates above.

I hope it may be possible to authorize this work immediately, so that the School will have the benefit of the chapel during the rest of
this term. It would be of great advantage to the Principal and
the Matron if the work could be done while the rest of the improve-
ments are being carried out, so that they would have all the work-
ment on the premises at the same time.

I hope arrangements have been made before this to carry
out the changes in the heating plant which were recommended by the
expert who visited the School at your request last year. Even now,
it is a fairly serious matter to have to let the fires out for any
length of time in a place where there are so many little children.

Assuring you that we deeply appreciate your interest
in this School and your continued co-operation, and with very kind
personal regards,

I am

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Sir:

Attending Mr. Turner Orr.

I am dealing with the paint of the buildings at the present time. To all of his work on a new basis, I find myself that the work is not going ahead with a satisfactory result due to the element weather and thus to the present time four of the buildings have been steel brushed, and two of the roofs have part of their primer coats. This work was done on clear mild days and the completion of the work will depend on weather conditions in future and under these circumstances a satisfactory job cannot be guaranteed.

Mr. Turner Orr suggests that if the two large barns can be completed this fall, the balance of the work will till next year and so I am about having them finished off by Christmas. We have had a lot of heavy work on this work and criticize severely the fact that Mr. Orr has not been working on the same as he was last fall, and I have had to do it. The result which is now evident to the layman is I would consider that it will take me half the shortest job possible.

In conclusion, I would say that if Mr. Turner Orr will complete the two large barns this fall, the result of the work will be more than by relief work by himself. In fact it could by my opinion all have been done in less if the equipment had been available.

I shall await Mr. Orr visit this Agency at an early date and give definite instructions in this regard ascertaining the facts of the situation and a report in the month of January.

Dear Sir;

I regret very much the necessity for drawing your attention to the following facts in connection with the plumbing repairs carried out at this school by Mr. Harvey J. Davis of Lambeth, Ont.

Mr. Davis submitted his account to Mr. Agent Moore and before sending the account forward for payment Mr. Moore inquired as to whether the work was satisfactory. I refused to accept the work as unsatisfactory and in his covering letter to my R.S.O., Mr. Moore so advised. However, without any investigation whatever the account was passed for payment. I hereby charge that there were items in this account that were not fair and just charges because they were for materials which were not supplied and for work that was not done, also there were items that were grossly overcharged.

I quote the following items as examples:

1. Materials and fittings for stack in girls' dormitory South Wing, $55.00
2. Repairing stack, girls' dormitory third floor, materials $55.00
   (In this case $6.00 would cover cost)
3. Wooden enclosure with necessary door and hardware, $20.00
   (In this case no material was supplied.)
4. Labor charges for taking out old and installing new toilet bowl and tank, $60.00 (This item could have been done by our school mechanic in about 6 hrs.)

I have quoted the above items to indicate the serious overcharging in this account which, I believe, amounts to over $400.00 in total. Mr. Davis called at the school one day last week and in the presence of Mr. Moore admitted, and agreed to correct the items which I challenged.

I have hesitated to bring to your attention the very unsatisfactory standard of the work executed, supposedly under the supervision of your architects branch, at this school during the last two years but this constitutes such a glaring example of mal-administration that I feel in duty bound to call it to your attention in order that action may be taken to protect this school against the possibility of a re-occurrence. The amount of this overcharge would go a long way towards the repairs to our heating system or the provision of an infirmary ward, both of which are very much needed at this time.

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

Principal.

Dear Dr. Cochrane:

Following our recent conference I beg to recommend the following repairs at this school as the necessary minimum.

Basement Rooms and Halls:

Girls recreation and assembly room: Strip loose plaster and re-plaster. Paint ceiling and walls. Screen wash basins.

Hall to dining-room: Strip plaster from ceiling and replaster. Paint walls.

Pupils' bath room: This room was fitted up as an emergency measure when the laundry tubs, in which the pupils had been bathed up until this time, were removed during the remodelling of the laundry building about two years ago. This room was used as a workshop and nothing was done beyond placing eight tub baths along one wall; connecting up the water and drain and changing the name from workshop to bathroom. The present condition is anything but sanitary and because of the location of the room it is impossible to adequately ventilate it without installing a proper exhaust ventilating system. A new floor should be laid so that proper drainage may be obtained, the walls should be resurfaced with a light colored hard wall plaster. The ceiling should be painted and three electric fixtures installed to give adequate lighting.

Pupils' kitchen: The wainscoting in this room is in a deplorable condition and should be removed entirely. The plaster on the ceiling is loose in a number of places and should be stripped off and the ceiling re-plastered. The walls should be resurfaced and painted. Two extra lights are needed. Proper cupboard space and utensil racks should be provided. A ventilating canopy should be provided above the stove to prevent cooking odours spreading throughout the building.

Pupils' dining room: Strip loose plaster from ceiling and replaster. Paint ceiling and walls, also all woodwork. Remove opaque glass from windows and replace with plain glass.

Boys' recreation & assembly room: During heavy rains the water seeps through the walls with the result that the wainscoting has rotted away. A tile drain should be provided to carry off the seepage. The wainscoting...
Rooms & Halls cont'd -

should be removed, the walls resurfaced, walls and woodwork painted.

Boys' wash room; Strip off loose plaster, re-surface walls with hard finish, paint walls and woodwork.

Main Floor.

Boys' reading room; Repair plaster, paint walls and woodwork, varnish ceiling, and install one extra lighting fixture.

Manual training room; This room is in fair condition.

Assembly room; At present being renovated.

Domestic Science and Staff Kitchen; Repair walls and ceiling, paint woodwork and walls, provide adequate cupboards and utensil racks.

Girls' reading room; Paint walls, ceiling and woodwork. Install one extra lighting fixture.

Sewing class-room; Paint walls and varnish ceiling.

First Floor.

Girls' dormitory; Repair plaster. Paint woodwork, walls and ceiling. Install exhaust ventilating fans and intake grilles.

Boys' dormitory; Repair plaster, paint woodwork, ceiling and walls. Install exhaust ventilating fans and intake grilles.

Second Floor.

Girls' dormitory; Repair plaster, paint woodwork, ceiling and walls. Install exhaust ventilating fans and intake grilles.

Boys' dormitory; Repair plaster, paint woodwork, ceiling and walls. Install exhaust ventilating fans and intake grilles.

Third Floor.

Centre room; Strip off plaster from ceiling and replaster. Repair walls and paint woodwork.

North rooms; This room is approximately 55 ft. long and 26 ft. wide and at present is not being used. I would suggest that it be fitted up for infirmary accommodation at the present time we have not a room in which we can isolate a sick pupil.

Stairways from Basement to Pupils' Dormitories.

All these stairways are in poor condition with the treads badly worn. All treads should be replaced, plaster repaired, all woodwork and walls painted.
This is something that does not at present exist. I would suggest that a modern cold storage room be installed in the vegetable storage room in the basement.

Heating Plant.

The heating plant consists of one low pressure boiler with steam radiators and gravity return system. It is hopelessly inadequate as at present installed. I would recommend the following alterations:

1. Installation of a small auxiliary boiler. (On two occasions during the last five years boiler tubes have given out and it has been necessary to draw the fires in mid-winter. Imagine 150 people in the school without a fire in the boiler in February.)

2. Installation of an automatic stoker with thermostat and blower fan.

3. Installation of a vacuum return pump to promote proper circulation of steam throughout the system.

Main Building Roof.

There are approximately 250 broken and cracked slates on the main roof and towers. During heavy rains the water soaks down through until the main roof timbers are beginning to show signs of decay. The whole roof should be carefully inspected and broken slates replaced. The towers while adding to the appearance of the building are really causing much of our trouble as during high winds they sway to such an extent that the building is rocked and it is impossible to prevent the plaster on the walls and ceilings from cracking and falling.

Annex Building.

In this building are located the three public school class rooms, the Herdsman's living quarters, the Mechanic's living quarters and three rooms for single members of the staff.

In 1934-5 considerable work was done with a view to remodelling this building. The south wall was badly bulged and in a dangerous condition; it was pulled down and rebuilt. In 1935 the east wall had to be pulled down and rebuilt and now the north wall is badly cracked and needs attention. At the time that the alterations were made to the Herdsman's and Mechanic's apartments no redecorations were included with the result that they are very much in need of redecorating throughout.

The senior class room is in good condition but the intermediate and primary rooms have a very patched up appearance and should be completely redecorated.

The architect of the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources visited this school and made a thorough inspection in 1934. A copy of his report was forwarded to Mr. Beaton's office April 17th, 1934 by Dr. H. W. McGill.
In his report the architect, Mr. Orr, proposes to re-plan the various floors of the building to use up waste space. After giving careful study to the plans of the building he is now convinced that re-planning is utterly impossible and impracticable. He insists that the only solution is a new building in the immediate future.

I find myself in complete agreement with Mr. Orr's decision. This school was in the first place planned for about 75 pupils, the dormitory space was extended to provide for 100 to 125. Our present registration is 134 and we are continually receiving applications from the Indian Agents for more admissions. Our pupilage has so far outgrown our physical equipment that we are working all the while at a decided disadvantage.

I sincerely hope that our Home Mission Board will see its way clear to recommend the building of a new fireproof school in the immediate future. The present buildings would burn like tinder if they once caught fire. The strain, upon the staff, of the constant vigilance necessary to prevent fire and the probable loss of life is very heavy. In a new school adequate provision should be made for vocational training in all branches as well as public school work.

Should you deem it desirable, I will be glad to come to Toronto and appear before the Board or any of its committees and answer any questions that may arise and present information that may be desired.

I enclose herewith a copy of my letter to Mr. Hoey, Superintendent of Welfare and Training.

Yours truly,

Sign'd - Oliver B. Strepp.
