Dear Sir;

I am in receipt of a telephone instruction from Mr. Agent Moore to the effect that you have issued authority for the employment of a night watchman for this school until fires in the main heating plant are discontinued. Mr. Moore informs me that he does not know whether this watchman is to be employed by me as a member of the staff of this school and therefore paid through my office or whether he is to be considered as a temporary employee of your department and paid through Mr. Moore's office.

I am sure that you will understand that it is rather difficult for me to know just what your intention is in the matter when all that I have as authority is a telephone communication.

I would very much appreciate direct communication upon all matters affecting the administration of this school, with, whenever necessary, a copy of the letter going to the local office for the information of the Agent. It is very difficult to keep the files of the school in proper order for reference purposes unless correspondence is available for filing.

I would respectfully suggest that in order to make the inspection of the building at regular intervals effective, a watchman's clock should be obtained and keys placed at stations throughout the building.

May I say that I appreciate very much your decision to employ a watchman as we have been very much concerned about the possibility of fire, as owing to the general construction of the building it would be very difficult to bring a fire under control if it once obtained a good start.

Awaiting your instructions in the matter,

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

Enclosed please find a voucher in favor of Mr. Harvey M. Davis, Lambeth, Ont., for $3,083.94 being for materials and work at the Mount Elgin Residential School, Muncey, as was authorized by your letter 7-0-5 of Sept. 21st, 1936.

The cost of this work has exceeded the estimate made by Mr. Davis by a considerable amount and also there has been work done that was not shown in the estimate and at the request of the Principal of the school, no authority having been given for additional work from this office.

I did request the Principal of the school to approve of this account, which he refused to do, complaining that Mr. Davis had not completed the work to his satisfaction in so far as the cement work at the toilets is concerned and that there are no covers on the water tanks of the toilets which he claims were to be installed and thereby stop the pupils from throwing articles in the water tanks of the toilets. On taking this matter up with Mr. Davis he informed me that the style of tanks installed are of the open variety and no tops are needed.

Before payment of this account is made I would suggest that the work be inspected by a departmental official and approved, as this work was all carried out under the supervision of the Principal and on his instructions and this office only gave instructions as to the work stated in the estimate given by Mr. Davis.

Secretary,
Dept of Ind. Affs.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

If you can do so, we would appreciate your advising us if Mr. Davis' representations to us are correct and the reason for the delay in paying the money over to him.

Mr. Mills:

I wish to report that in accordance with instructions contained in Mr. Wardle's memorandum of April 6th, I made an inspection of the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School, at Muncey, on Monday and Tuesday, April 26th and 27th.

With regard to the Annex Building this building was erected as the original building, in 1883, and enlarged in 1886. During the past few years considerable improvements have been made to this building, which now contains three classrooms and living quarters for two of the staff.

The South wall of this building was torn down and rebuilt two years ago. The cement facing plaster over the masonry walls at that time was poorly applied and is now partially loose, flaking and peeling off. This surface should be entirely stripped and replaced with 1/2 inch cement plaster coating, carefully and properly applied.

The North wall of the same building has settled considerably and has left this wall in an unsound condition. Although the wall is now structurally unsound and might easily remain serviceable for several years, precaution should be taken to keep it against complete fracture. The accompanying diagram, No. 1, shows a sectional diagram of the surface cracks. Although it is impossible to see the actual brick well behind the plaster facing, this facing is very sound and the surface cracks can be considered as cracks in the masonry wall. Two methods of precaution are possible for this wall, depending on the intentions of the Indian Affairs Branch.

1. If the building is only to be used for a few years it would be more economical to merely brace the wall from outside with timber buttresses.

2. If the building is to be used indefinitely the wall will have to be torn down and rebuilt. Nothing will not be considered advisable as a settlement for both the Annex Building and the Main Building. The unsoundness due to the erosion of the river bank causing a general settlement of the land all along the North side of the property. Thus, any expensive repair work at the moment...
moment would undoubtedly be undermined in a short time. This settling action is also affecting the North end of the Main building which parallels the Annex Building.

With regard to the main building the brick arches are flattening and dislodging brick along the underside of the arches. This loosening can only be explained by the settlement of the building at the North end, which would tend to remove the lateral support over the arches. The accompanying diagrams, Nos. 2 and 3, explain this action. These dislodged bricks can easily be replaced at a very small cost.

The general layout of the buildings mentioned above and other buildings of the Institute is shown on the accompanying diagram, No.4. After a general survey of the Annex and Main Building I would recommend extensive or expensive repairs to either buildings. The general condition of the interior are not ideal, but under the circumstances it can be maintained and operated for the present.

A general survey of the conditions in the residence shows that the plaster walls and ceilings are badly cracked; plaster loose; and in many places has fallen off; floors need refinishing in many places; in the boys' bedroom the floor has buckled in three or four places; stair treads are worn thin; in general the walls are badly soiled and in need of redecoration.

Structurally the towers above the central portion of the School are very detrimental to the building, as in high winds they sway and cause cracks in the building. As a result of this motion there are cracks leaking in the roof which result in saturation of the interior walls and ceiling. This has rotted the wood facing beneath the eaves around the building. The brick walls have many settlement cracks in places where the bricks should be repointed or removed and rebuilt.

The boiler room at the rear of the building should be torn down and rebuilt, as the walls are in very poor condition and the roof leaks badly.

The heating system is very unsatisfactory during cold weather, and its condition should be reported on by a competent heating engineer.

In a general report two years ago the Architect of the Department of Indian Affairs estimated a cost of $15,000 to renovate and improve the building for satisfactory operation, and in subsequent reports advised against renovation as he did not consider the buildings worth it.

(sgd.) J. E. DUDLEY

Muncey, Ont., July 10th, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 29th, with reference to the proposed improvements to the heating system at the Mount Elgin Residential School and not being familiar with this system I did request the Rev. Principal of the school to give the necessary information.

Mr. Strapp reports that the number of radiators requiring diaphragms, new tops and orifice plates on the valves is sixty-nine. One radiator will require the removal of a cracked section.

Regarding the general repairs and regrading of pipes and installation of drip traps Mr. Strapp reports that this information can only be obtained by an expert with the necessary levels.

With further reference to repairs at Mount Elgin School Mr. Strapp reports a very severe leak in the roof of the main building that needs attention, also that the lightning rod system needs overhauling on the buildings many of which are useless due to broken ground wires, etc. These repairs could be looked into on your next visit to this Agency, which I understand will be in the near future.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I would advise you that the Rev. Principal of Mount Elgin School has brought to my attention the urgent need of repairs to the ceiling of the second floor boys' dormitory.

It would be necessary to engage a white plasterer for this work and the repaired ceiling would have to be repapered.

Memorandum: Mr. Mills.

Re - Repairs to the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School.

With reference to the heating repairs to the Mount Elgin School the firms of Douglas and Innis, Gloucester; Herbert Frank, Stratford; and George Brewer, Parkhill, were contacted on Friday afternoon, October 26th, but all were unable to visit the school until Saturday morning. Mr. Innis and Mr. Frank reported at Mount Elgin School and a thorough inspection was made of the existing heating system. Mr. Brewer did not report. Mr. Innis phoned his office stating that he was busy and did not wish to tender on the work. After the inspection Mr. Innis and Mr. Frank were requested to submit their estimate covering the material and labour required. Due to the necessity of securing prices from suppliers on some of the equipment their prices were not available until Tuesday evening. On Tuesday evening the following quotations were received:

Douglas & Innis - Materials $1,090.00 Labour $160.00 Total $1,250.00

Herbert Frank - $1,445.92 Total $1,568.92

These prices were then forwarded to the Chief Engineer at Ottawa, and instructions were received by wire on Wednesday evening, October 29th, to place the work with the firm of Douglas and Innis. On Thursday, October 30th, Douglas and Innis were advised that their tender was satisfactory and they were requested to begin work as soon as possible in accordance with the General Conditions, Labour Conditions, and Specifications pertaining to the heating repairs. This work is to begin about October 27th and should be completed in ten days.

With regard to the General Repair work at the Mount Elgin School, Mr. John Drake of Stratford, was asked Thursday morning and requested to report at Ministry. Mr. Drake reported Thursday afternoon, October 26th, and a general survey was made of the repair work. The work was outlined, and discussed and on Saturday morning, October 28th, a bill of materials was drawn up and orders placed with local firms for materials required. Mr. Drake was informed as to hiring of labour, rates, etc., and arrangements to commence work immediately. Mr. Frank Stafford was recommended for the plastering work, and Indian labour for all other work was to be secured through the Indian Agent. Due to the Canada Fair, Indian labour will not be available until Thursday, October 31st, at which time the work will be started.

Assistant Architect.

Dear Sir;

For some years the roof of the main boiler room of the school has been in a state of dis-repair. It is in such a condition now that unless immediate repairs are made a new roof will have to be placed at considerable expense and in the meantime serious damage is likely to occur to the heating equipment. I took the matter up with your Mr. Dudley when he was here and he advised me that it would be necessary for me to write to you for authority as the repair would be separate from what is being carried out under his supervision at present.

As the firm of Douglas & Sons who are executing the repairs to the heating system are general contractors and carry a large stock of roofing materials I took the liberty of asking them to quote a price so that I might be able to state the probable cost in my letter to you. I beg to enclose herewith their quotation and request authority to have the work carried out as soon as possible.

With reference to the repairs to the heating plant I may say that for the first time since I entered the school in 1929 I have been able to go into the boys' dormitory and feel that they were at least reasonably comfortable. I may say that it is now possible to heat the whole building with very little trouble. I wish to express my very sincere appreciation of your consideration in this matter and to assure you of the co-operation of the staff and myself in the carrying out of the program of education for the Indian people.

I remain,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter 7-0-5 of June 7th, I would advise that Mr. Strapp, Principal of Mount Elgin School, has obtained and submitted to this office an estimate of the carpenter work and decorating work he wishes done at Mount Elgin Residential School and which, when completed, would be chargeable to the $1000.00 available for repairs and improvements at this school.

Dear Sir:

Attention Mr. R. A. Hoey,

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter 7-0-5 of October 1st enclosing account submitted by John A. Drake, Strathroy, Ontario, for materials and labour at Mount Elgin Residential School amounting to $104.31 on which you ask for further information.

When Mr. Drake compiled his estimate at the request of the Rev. Principal it was for repairs to be made on a dwelling house formerly occupied by one of the staff which had been vacant for a number of years and was in a bad state of repair. This estimate was forwarded to the Department through this office on August 16th and was satisfactory to the Principal but after Mr. Drake had commenced work it was found instead of needing only 150 brick to fix the chimneys it required 400 and extra labour and the chimneys had to be rebuilt completely.

In estimating the plastering needing repair, Mr. Drake only estimated patching whereas it was found that practically all the old plaster had to be removed and fresh plaster applied. Mr. Drake was also short in his estimate of the needs of locks on the doors of this dwelling nearly all of which had to be replaced with new locks.
The cost of materials and labour on these three items was responsible for the increase in the account and Mr. Drake was requested to do this work on the instructions of Rev. O. B. Strapp, Principal of the school.

Voucher no. 240 is returned herewith and is recommended for payment.

Your obedient servant,

Enclosure.

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,

AGENT'S REPORT

Respecting the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School

For the month of February 1939.

ROUTINE

At the time of my visit there were:
- 124 pupils in the classrooms.
- Are the classroom registers kept up to date? Yes
- 30 pupils in vocational training departments.
- 2 pupils sick.
- 1 pupil absent. Reasons: Truant whom police cannot locate.
- Total number on roll: 157

Are there any pupils in residence whose admission has not been approved by the Department?
- No

HEALTH, SANITATION, Etc.

Appearance of pupils: Pupils appear well dressed.
Cleanliness of school: All buildings kept clean and tidy.
Appearance of school grounds: Well kept.
Care of the sick: Well cared for by the Agency Med. Supt. and School Nurse.
The children's meals: Potato soup, peanut butter, fruit cake, bread & milk.
Fire drill, escapes and protection: Adequate fire escapes, fire hose and equipment.

VOCATIONAL TRAINING

Domestic instruction: Grades 4 to 8 under direction of graduate dietitian.
Instruction in farming and gardening: Grades 4 to 8 under qualified farm foreman.
Training in the care of live stock: Grades 4 to 8 under qualified herdsmen & poultryman.
Manual training: Wood work, brass pounding, weaving and metalwork taught to selected pupils.
Care of agricultural machinery and other equipment: Stored in implement sheds.

GENERAL

Discipline at the school: Good.
Efficiency of the staff: Appear quite efficient.
General management: Good.

Suggestions: Repairs badly needed to valley caves, troughing and conductor pipes on main school building and wings. Estimated 50 slate shingles needed to stop roof leaks. Total cost in the vicinity of $200.00.

Indian Agent

Form No. 217
Muncey, February 9th, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed Agent's report on a visit of inspection made to Muncye Indian Residential School on February 6th and at the time of this visit the Rev. Principal drew my attention to leaks in the roof of the main building due to broken and missing slates and he estimates in the vicinity of fifty new slates are necessary at forty cents each to make these repairs.

The Principal also reported the need of replacing a considerable portion of the Valley eavestroughing on the main building which eavestroughing, due to age, has rusted and is full of holes and the water leaks in and causes considerable damage to the building and should be renewed. The conductor pipes on both the wings of the school proper are missing, having been broken off and the pipe is full of holes and needs replacing as it is doing harm to the brick work and the school is losing rain water that they generally use for the purpose of making fuel or repairing eavestroughing and conductor pipes is uncertain and only a tinsmith could estimate accurately. The Principal considers repairs could be made if $175.00 were made available.

The brass pounding and weaving work is going ahead very successfully and the pupils enjoy this and other manual training work and have shown a marked aptitude by the finished articles they have made.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed Agent's Report form on a visit of inspection made to the Mount Elgin Indian Residential school on the 29th of June.

The Rev. O. B. Strapp, Principal of this School requests that additional space be provided to accommodate his classes in weaving and makes a suggestion that for $500.00 he could erect a suitable building and use the present concrete root-cellar for the foundation of such a building.

I am not enthused at the idea of building new additions at Mount Elgin School and do consider that the present buildings being old will soon need a large expense in repairs and upkeep and that consideration should soon be given to the erection of a new modern school, providing it is intended to go into an extensive manual training programme. I also believe that through the aid being given Indians to re-establish themselves on their reserves, there should be less need of placing children in a residential school like Mount Elgin in future years and that children will be reared by their parents and not in a boarding school.

If a policy of sending fewer children to a residential school like Mount Elgin was pursued and the enrollment cut by a third at least it would leave a lot of space available at the school to use for manual training and technical training, without building additional buildings. It is suggested that an official of the Department visit Mount Elgin school at an early date to make a complete report in this connection and its future possibilities.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Please let me have detailed information regarding the material required in order that purchase may be made through our purchasing branch. Dear Sir;

Confirming my last letter of Oct. 15th, I would advise that the toilets in the three local institutions at Mount Elgin Residential School are out of order and need immediate attention.

When Mr. Brown and Armstrong visited me of this school a few weeks ago, Mr. Brown went up to the roof of Mount Elgin, Ont., to see where the water pipe was located. It was found that the well pipe from these toilets was located badly and filled with refuse from the third floor to the basement and that it would not be advisable to use these old pipes, which have been there since the school was built, forty-five years ago, and that the most economical method in the long run would be to replace over 30 feet of this well pipe with new heavy construction.

As the cost of the work will be high and the school in the building budget, I recommend Mr. Armstrong to proceed at once with the work so that the new materials and labor needed by the school will not be in the way but of $75.00 and I could find some approval of this expenditure.

I am not totally confident in quite such matters, as he has probably seen fit to do in the past.

Extract from Inspector Young's report on the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School visited on March 27, 1941.

In the sewing room two new sewing machines are urgently needed. In view of the fact that the girls secure positions, either domestic or commercial, where electric machines are used, one or both of these ought to be driven electrically so that the girls may learn the operation of such machines.
Muncey, Ontario,
May 2nd, 1941.

Dear Sir:

On May 1st the Rev. O. B. Strapp, Principal of Mount Elgin School advised me that the main drain coupled with the septic tank laundry in barns was blocked up and on visiting the school to inspect the drain I find that at the outlet where the drain enters into the River Muncey a third of a mile distant from the school buildings, over 150 feet of the drain has caved in and the outlet tiles are all broken. This tile drain is 15 feet deep at its outlet and until it is dug out it will not be possible to find where the stoppage occurs and it would be necessary to commence at the outlet and work backwards.

The drain was put in many years ago and Mr. Strapp does not know of its construction and it may be possible that it is a 10" field tile or a wooden box drain. This can only be found out when the drain is opened.

In view of the depth of the drain it will be expensive to open the same but it should be done at once so that water and refuse will not back up into the school buildings through the septic tank. As the overflow from the septic tank, the drains from the main building, the barns and the cultivated fields all empty into this outlet, it is therefore important to me myself that the septic tank outlet should be on a separate drain and carried to the river at its closest point from the tank which would greatly shorten the length of such outlet and it is suggested that the Department send an Official at an early date to investigate and report as a large expenditure will be involved in any case.

Pending your instructions I will at once engage men to open this drain to try and eliminate the present blockage and will pay wages from our Welfare Account to be reimbursed at a later date from the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

for A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

August 9th, 19—

Dear Sir:

I would advise that Rev. O. B. Strapp, Principal of Mt. Elgin School, has informed me that some repair work on the ceiling is urgently needed in the primary classroom in the annex building of the school. On inspection of the room I found that the plaster on the ceiling has cracked in many places and small portions of it have already fallen off. If this is not repaired it will be a menace to the pupils in the room and I would recommend that the classroom be repaired as soon as possible.

The ceiling of the classroom is 32 ft. long and 25 ft. wide and Mr. Strapp and I agree that it should be covered with Tentest material instead of plaster. It would take 300 ft. of Tentest \(\frac{1}{4}\)" thick at an estimated cost of $68.32 plus 20 lineal ft. of 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" lattice stripping at a cost of $4.32. The labour in putting on the Tentest would be approximately $20.00 making a total estimated expenditure of $68.32.

Walls of this classroom need painting as do the ceilings in all five rooms of the northern end of second-floor apartment in the annex building. About seven gallons of paint costing $31.50 would be necessary. Two gallons of turpentine, one gallon of boiled oil and three pounds of ordinary glue to fill in the cracks in the plaster on the walls before painting would be necessary. It would require about two gallons of grey paint paid for by the ceilings of the apartment rooms and three gallons of buff paint for the walls of the classroom. According to the Principal, this painting could be done with a spray gun by the pupils of the school and no labour costs in painting would be involved.

The total estimated cost of the materials for the above would be $24.00 and labour in putting on the Tentest would be $20.00.

I would recommend that authority be granted to purchase the materials locally so that there will be no delay and the repairs effected before school reopens on Sept. 1st. Suitable Indian labour is very scarce now and I would wish authority to employ white labour to put on the Tentest as Indians cannot be obtained to do the work which is very doubtful at the present time. Payment of labour and materials would be made by voucher from the Department if the expenditure is approved.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken, In Charge
Garadoc Agency.

Dear Sir,

Your File 7-0-5.

Replying to your letter of June 18th re; improvements at the Mount Elgin Institute.

After a careful inspection, in company with Mr. Strapp, it was decided that the amount available for improvements, in the present fiscal year, namely $350.00, could be used to better advantage in a general way. That is, rather than any elaborate undertaking, a number of very necessary repairs. For instance, the boys' playroom is in a very dilapidated condition; the drainage in the girls' wash room; the roof needs patching in several places; some painting to be done and other little jobs.

It would be almost impossible to submit an intelligent report as to materials required, as the work to be done is more or less a series of local contracts and would have to be let, in some cases with the contractor supplying his own materials. For instance, it is a slate roof and we cannot decide the number of slates required and the other jobs are somewhat of the same nature, and the material would have to be purchased as required.

Owing to the difficulty in securing help, I would suggest that I receive prices on the different jobs, purchase whatever materials are necessary, as we go along. It will then be a simple matter to keep within the allotted amount.

Dear Sir:

As you are aware, we have purchasing regulations which require that when expenditures for material amount to more than $50.00 purchase has to be made through the Purchasing Branch. Under these circumstances there is no alternative except to forward to us detailed information regarding materials necessary, and we will endeavour to secure them at the earliest possible date. You realize, of course, that it is difficult to obtain many articles, due to present conditions, and when securing materials that are available, delay is unavoidable. Attention Mr. Phelan.

Dear Sir,

Re: repairs to Mt. Elgin Institute

Your File 7-0-5

Your letter of July 13th has been giving Mr. Strapp and me much thought and planning and we find it almost impossible to submit a list of materials that could be intelligently submitted to the Purchasing Agent.

As I pointed out in my previous letter, we had decided to use the $500.00 for general repair jobs, rather than concentrate on any one particular improvement. For instance, one job would be to repair the roof which is not only in a bad state of repair and causing damage to the ceilings in the dormitories, but is very high and laid with slate. This type of work, owing to the smooth surface is very dangerous to the inexperienced. In this connection, I have made inquiries and my information is, that the men who repair these types of roofs, usually supply their own slates and make a charge per slate laid. Apparently, it is the only way this job could be done. Then we decided to repair the boys playroom. This has been a half wainscoted room with a plaster top, but owing to the continual repairing of the wainscoting it was thought, it would be wise to tear it out and replace it with a cement plaster wall. There are also several repair jobs to ceilings, caused through rain leaking down through the roof. The wash rooms also need minor repairs, etc., etc.

In all these repairs, you will of course understand, owing to our isolated position, how difficult it is to get a workman to drive in for the sole purpose...
of submitting an estimate on any one of these jobs, especially under gasoline rationing and the rubber situation.

The quantities of any one material needed for the several repair jobs would be small and could be purchased on a basis of requirements as needed.

However, I would suggest that this explanation be submitted to the Purchasing Agent's Office, with a view to granting permission to proceed with the work through local purchases of material as required, otherwise, I am afraid I cannot submit intelligent estimates unless I am prepared to provide transportation for the different tradesmen, to come in for the sole purpose of submitting estimates. Even then, I think it would be more or less on work than material.

Your obedient servant,

G. W. Down,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Rev. O. B. Strapp, Principal of the Muncey School, was in yesterday and brought with him a letter which he had received from the Tire Controller. Mr. Strapp had applied for three retreads and one new tire for his car. The Controller writes:

"It is regretted that existing tire regulations do not provide for the supplying of replacement tires for the vehicle which is described in your application and, therefore, it will be impossible for us to grant the permit which is requested." (Sgd.: "Ross D. Borrett, Room 2111, #3 Building - File C.S. 4M)

I hope you will find it possible in some way to take this up and have these regulations amended. Otherwise, I am afraid we shall be under the painful necessity of closing the Muncey School. You may say that this is an extreme view to take; but the fact is that this School is twenty miles from London, which is the nearest town, and you will realize that it is quite impossible to carry on work at this School without having a car to go into London on business and take the teachers and members of the staff for weekend leave. If Mr. Strapp were a minister on a small rural field with three appointments, he would, without any question, get the tire ration which he requests, and I have no hesitation in saying that this School is far more important than a small pastoral charge. It is true that Mr. Strapp has a truck, but he cannot take any passengers in the truck and it is far more expensive to operate.

I do not think that the Church or the Department would be making an unreasonable request in asking for reconsideration of this ruling. I should be glad if you would take the matter up through the proper officials and let us know as soon as possible whether Mr. Strapp can get this necessary permit.

Mr. Strapp has also asked me to write about the possibility of getting some priority ratings for the Muncey School - I presume this will apply to other Schools as well. He finds it impossible to carry on his work unless he gets something like that. For example, he has a welding outfit which enables him to do many repairs which are necessary. He cannot get supplies for this unless he gets some priority rating.

Re: Priority Ratings

May I refer to your letter of August 18, 1942, in which you seek information in respect to the steps that should be taken by you to secure a priority rating that would enable you to purchase certain supplies necessary from time to time at your school.

The Purchasing Agent now informs us that it is not possible to secure a rating for your school or a rating that would enable you to purchase the supplies necessary in mind. His suggestion is that the supplies necessary at the school be purchased by the Purchasing Division of this Department and that a financial settlement be worked out immediately following each transaction. I must say that I am not at all satisfied with this ruling. If the officials responsible for issuing priority ratings from time to time refuse to give ratings to our schools, I find it difficult to see how we can keep these schools open and in operation. However, I feel rather helpless in regard to the whole matter. I appreciate very fully, after my visit to your school, the urgent need at the institution for certain supplies and certain repairs. I have informed you that the officials here that I would not tolerate the conditions at your school 24 hours if they were coming in contact with them, as you are, from day to day. In view of the fact that it is the intention of the Churches to interview the Government at an early date would it be possible for you to bring this matter to their attention and the Secretary of the Home Mission Board? I make this suggestion because it seems to me that the securing of supplies for our schools - always a difficult matter - has reached a stage when it is almost impossible to secure supplies at all.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

T. R. L. MacInnes, Secretary, Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of Dec. 9, re repairs at the Mt. Elgin Institute. In this connection I am wondering whether or not the Home Missions' Board of the United Church were also advised as to the difficulties we are experiencing in securing responsible labour of any kind, especially in our isolated position.

On learning of the current year's appropriation no time was lost in discussing with the Rev. Mr. O. B. Strapp, Principal of the Mt. Elgin Institute, the most important necessary repairs. Previous correspondence will bear this out and every endeavour was made to get estimates on the various repairs, without avail. This can be attributed to one or several reasons,—shortage of responsible labour, gasoline rationing, tire conservation or perhaps an indifference to working on and in such a building. Whatever the cause, I have to date been unable to locate a responsible man capable of doing the work. Mr. Strapp, on his own initiative, hired an Indian to tear up some drains. The necessary pipes were ordered and after delivery, which was within a few days of ordering, his Indian disappeared. He has recently returned to finish his job but I think the stench got the better of him as he is now on sick leave. What is badly needed at this Institution is a little more cooperation and less criticising.

However, as far as the Mt. Elgin Institute is concerned, and it is not my intention to enter into any lengthy controversy, I am at a standstill. Tire, gasoline and wear and tear will not permit the unrestricted use of

p.t.o.
my car in locating a man and correspondence is useless. However, the Home Missions Board know of capable men, in the close vicinity, badly in need of work and will advise them to get in touch with this office, I can assure them that every consideration will be given to see that they are promptly put to work.

In conclusion Mr. Hoey, since assuming responsibility of this Agency I have been a very, very, busy man. I am still busy and such a report from the Mission Board of the United Church with its glaring inception is not appreciated.

G. W. Down,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Some consideration should be given to repairs that may be necessary to enable the School to carry on until its future is definitely decided. Mr. Strapp came in to see me yesterday and suggested that, if he could get $500.00 made available, he could make the basement a good deal more satisfactory than it is at the present time, and also make some other necessary minor repairs to the building. Do you think it would be possible to make $500.00 available to Mr. Strapp, so that he could use it for day labour? I should be glad to hear from you about this.

November 5th, 1943.

Mr. George W. Down,
Indian Agent,
Muncey,
Ontario.

Dear Sir;

Upon receipt of your communication re Night Watchman,
I sent a note to Mr. Seneca, I enclose his reply.

I feel sure that it will be necessary for the Department to increase
the grant to at least $50.00 per month in order to secure anyone sufficiently
responsible and trustworthy for the position. Men who can now earn #2.50
per cord for cutting stove wood will not work a whole month for two weeks
pay.

I beg to suggest that you bring this to the attention of the Indian Affairs
Branch, and request the increase in the grant.

It is very necessary that we have someone on the job as soon as possible
as of course I cannot expect my regular staff to get up during the night
to make the necessary patrols.

I remain,

Yours truly,

February 28, 1944.

Reverend Sir:

The following letter dated February 24 has just been received from the Royal Bank of Canada, London, Ontario:

"Mt. Elgin Indian Residential School

"We are carrying on our books the above account opened under date of July 16, 1943, with an initial deposit of $500.00 which amount, we understand, represented proceeds of a cheque issued from your office.

"According to our records, the Rev. O.B. Strapp as principal of the school is in full charge but during our recent inspection it was noted that we did not hold covering authority from your office giving this party power to operate the account.

A few days ago we sent forward to Mr. Jackson, for his consideration, a request we had received for certain repairs to the roof of the Mount Elgin Institute.

I pointed out to him that the Back Settlement School had been destroyed by fire; that the school at Stoney Point had been abandoned and sold for a residence and that in view of these facts the closing of the Mount Elgin Institute could scarcely be considered at this particular time. Re: Roof Repairs
Mount Elgin Institute

I have received your letter of May 6th relative to the necessary repairs to the roof of the above Institute and enclosing an estimate from Kenneth Elson, Parkhill, Ontario, for $1,863.75.

An examination of this large slated roof was made yesterday and I find that the roof appears to be in reasonably good condition. On the various sides small numbers of slates are missing and these spaces have mostly been filled in with galvanized iron. The main leakage is caused by snow melting and being held on the roof by four cornices. To correct this condition and permit the water to run freely into the eavestroughs it is considered necessary to cut off the ends of the cornices. In addition, four valleys have broken slates which require replacement and the valley iron repainted with an asphalt composition.

The eavestroughing around the building is in need of cleaning. Some places are clogged with dead leaves and birds' nests as well as pieces of broken slate.

It is my opinion that this repair work, while necessary, is of a more minor nature than that indicated.
by Mr. Elean's estimate.

I have asked Mr. Strapp to get in touch with a roofing contractor already known to him, in London, Ontario, who previously examined the roof and submitted an estimate, and to solicit from him a new estimate and failing this to try to contact a competent slater who might consider doing the work on a labour basis under the direction of the Agent or Principal.

It is my opinion that the necessary labour plus material could be secured and the roof adequately repaired for a sum not exceeding $500.00

This repair work is not of great urgency but should be done before another winter. The leakage through melting snow being held each Spring from the cornices has existed for years and is aggravated when the snowfall is heavy. The valley iron should be painted and the broken slates renewed also before another winter. The eaves-troughs can be cleaned at any time. The School Principal states he is unable to have this work done owing to the absence from the School on farm work of the larger boys.

Mr. Strapp has intimated that he will communicate direct with Mr. Hoey when additional estimates or other information has been received.

I might add in giving this opinion of the approximate cost and urgency of repairs to this large slate roof that perhaps it would be better to have an architect make a more careful examination, and having in mind that the roof repairs do not solve the problem of this building I would not recommend that any greater sum than that of my estimate be expended without a careful examination by a building expert.

During a recent visit to the Mt. Elgin Residential School it was my pleasure to meet and talk with the Rev. Mr. Soper. Mr. Soper, as you are aware, is the new Principal recently appointed by the Home Mission Board of the United Church of Canada. The purpose of my visit was to inspect the principal's quarters and make a survey of the farm buildings. In conclusion, however, owing to Mr. Soper's desire and his sincere demonstration of will to co-operate, was much more intensive than I had intended. I am, therefore, passing on, in the form of a memorandum, a survey of the school buildings used exclusively for the accommodation of staff and pupils together with a few suggestions that would brighten and add to the comfort of all in residence.

In the main building adjoining the principal's quarters there is accommodation for staff in the form of three bedrooms, bath and one sitting room. Two of these bedrooms and bathrooms were decorated in 1943. I am suggesting that the remaining bedroom and sitting room be decorated this year.

In the same building the girls' dormitory, as referred to in Mr. Young's report and mentioned in your letter to the Rev. O.B. Stepp dated June 14th, needs brightening up. Paint will do this but of course it will not repair the floors, ceilings and sanitary system, all of which are major repair jobs.

My particular attention was drawn to the exits leading to the fire escapes. These exits are in the form of double sash windows and in every case, throughout the whole dormitory system, these exits were padlocked. I asked if this were the general procedure when all pupils were in residence and upon whose orders they were locked. I was told yes under orders of the Governing Principal, the reason being an endeavor to stop runaways. I registered strong disapproval with such a procedure and pointed out that it would be better to have runaways than have one child burned to death. I also pointed out that responsibility would rest directly with the person giving the order. I also stressed that fire exits and escape should be unbarred by any obstruction and ready for immediate exit and escape at all times. I would suggest that I be authorized to have these padlocks immediately removed and that in the meantime consideration be given to having the windows removed and replaced with doors equipped with regular panic bars, as suggested in your letter of June 14th.
In the basement I visited the pupils' dining hall. This is one of the most depressing rooms in the main building. The air is foul, the lighting is poor and it is badly in need of brighter decorating. For air circulation, a built-in, wall fan is suggested. Such an installation would be a great improvement and have a beneficial effect of relieving the room of the musty staleness. While it is located in the basement the light cannot be improved by natural light but it can be considerably improved artificially by using larger wattage bulbs and the installing of two more lights. The present colour scheme is both dark and dingy and could be greatly improved by a new paint job. With these suggested improvements it would add new life and could not help but react favourably on the pupils.

Adjoining this hall is the kitchen, also various store rooms, wash rooms and play rooms all in need of various repairs, so much so that only a major repair job could be entertained.

Immediately behind the main building is what is referred to as the classrooms. This is a two-story brick, 90' by 30', with exterior plastered walls. The north end of this building is bulging and the experts say that at the present time it is being held in place by a work of art, namely, 2 by 8 planks. On the ground floor there are three classrooms all more or less in need of decorating and all in need of better lighting. Above the classrooms there are three apartments all in need of various repairs and repainting. These apartments are approached by outside, uncovered wooden stairs all in a very dangerous, rotted condition. After a final inspection of the exterior and interior of this building I might recommend minor decorating but the logical recommendation would be complete demolition and rebuild.

To the south of this building is the laundry, 40' by 30'. This is a two-story building in fair repair. The ground floor is equipped with regular laundry tubs and sinks and appears to be in good running condition. The second floor appears to have been used for anything one had a mind to do. It is dirty, untidy and smelly and is a glaring example of neglect.

Immediately south of this building is a frame building, 42' by 15'. This is known as the Manual Training building. It is 14½' tall,缺少信息，无法继续。

Dear Doctor Dorey:

Mr. Arneil is very anxious that I should accompany him when he visits Muncey on or about August 9, with the object of coming to an agreement with respect to the use of the farm buildings at the residential school. Mr. Arneil is at present engaged in an inspection trip of northern agencies but will return to Ottawa Saturday August 5. If he returns on that date, he and I might drive to Toronto on the 7th. Dear Mr. Down;

In reference to your recent visit to the school and Inspection of the Pump In the Steam Laundry may I say that The Beatty Bros Ltd estimate that the new pump will cost $210 less three percent cash, and about $10.00 labour and fittings.

The whole Laundry depends on this thirty year old pump and it is likely to play out any day now. I would appreciate your early recommendation in this matter.

Yours very sincerely,

S.H. Soper
During a recent visit to the Mt. Elgin Residential School the Rev. Mr. Soper drew my attention to a pump used in the laundry of that Institution. The pump, it appears, is an old one and leaks badly around the valves. A pump man was called in and Mr. Soper advises that, owing to its age and the fact that parts are not available, he, the mechanic, will not touch it. Mr. Soper has since written Beatty Brothers for a price on a new installation which I submit herewith.

Owing to the fact that the laundry operates only once a week, and that there would be ample time, I suggested that the pump be dismantled as it may be equipped with leather valves which need replacing; or perhaps gaskets are worn out. But between the mechanic and Mr. Soper they appear to have decided that it is definitely worn out. Maybe it is but I would like to examine the working parts before I recommend this expenditure. However, the request for a replacement is submitted for your consideration.

Geo. W. Down,

Re Survey:
Mt. Elgin Residential School

Reporting on my recent survey of barns and outbuildings at the Mt. Elgin Residential School, as requested in your letter of July 3rd, I know of no better way than to take you on an imaginary tour. To enable you to readily visualize positions and approximate distances from the main school buildings, I have prepared a rough plan which is herewith attached. To further assist I have numbered the buildings in order of our travel.

Starting from a point south is Building No. 1. This is a large barn, 100' by 50', with annex attached 27' by 40'. The main building is constructed of slop cement stabling, wall with hip roof, upper structure all steel storage barn with cement silo attached. It is in first class condition throughout and fully equipped to house a large number of any type of farm animal.

Travelling north a distance of approximately 200', we enter Building No. 2. This is a T-shaped barn measuring 100' by 40' and 70' by 30'. It has the same construction as No. 1 with two silos attached. It is in first class condition and especially equipped with steel stanchions and steel stalls to house approximately 100 head of cattle. It is, without doubt, one of the most up-to-date farms in Western Ontario.

Travelling north a distance of approximately 150', we enter Building No. 3. This is an L-shaped building 30' by 50' and 50' by 60'. The 30' by 50' is in a dilapidated, unsafe condition and should be demolished. The 30' by 60' is an implement shed in a good state of repair.

Travelling north a distance of approximately 100', we enter Building No. 4. This is a brick building 25' by 16'. The owner here is confused but at some time it has been used as a general repair for farm machinery. It is in need of major repairs.

Turning west and travelling a distance of approximately 75', we enter Building No. 5, 60' by 20'. This is an all steel, dirt floor implement shed in a first class condition throughout.
Turning south we travel a distance of approximately 100' and enter Building No. 6, 40' by 66'. This building has a brick foundation stabling with an all steel upper structure hay barn. It is equipped exclusively for horses having fourteen individual stalls and one box-stall. It is in first class condition.

Travelling south and passing the main School buildings, a distance of approximately 500 ft., we enter Building No. 7. This is a two-story brick building, 24' by 24'. It is used as a general store house and the raising of early chickens. Some work on the outside brick is necessary to put this building in good repair.

Turning west we travel a distance of approximately 250' and enter Building No. 8. This is a one-story, 20' by 50', frame henhouse in good condition.

The water system, throughout, is supplied from springs located on Indian property and is, I think, under long term lease. It is piped and pumped into pressure tanks and as far as is known, it has never failed.

Root storage facilities consist of two rooms, 14' by 24' each, both dry and suitable for any type of storage; also, one room, 15' by 40'. The smell here is very bad and the place is musty and wet. However, its location lends itself readily to drainage and I think that is all it needs to correct the condition.

This completes our tour and general survey of the farm buildings; and I would say constitute one of the finest and most up-to-date set of farm buildings in Western Ontario. Under proper management and with the lease land attached they could be made to serve the full requirements of the Mt. Elgin Residential School, not only in the matter of providing food for the pupils and staff but one of the most up-to-date instructional centres for all Indians in Ontario, west of Toronto. There would of course, changes and perhaps a few problems before realization of a plan could materialize, but nothing of a nature that cooperation could not overcome.

In submitting this report please keep in mind that it is merely a report on the barns and outbuildings in an endeavour to enable you to decide as to the advisability of renting or utilizing them in our general Welfare program as suggested in your letter of July 3rd.

Geo. T. Down,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Ottawa;

On receipt of your letter of the 19th regarding the Solomon children of Cape Croker I wired Mr. F.W.Tuffnell telling him that we would accept the children but they would have to wait till roads were opened. May 4th, 1945.

I attach herewith several letters recently received from the Rev. Mr. Soper, Principal of the Mt. Elgin Residential School which are self-explanatory in so far as they refer to repairs to the School. For convenience I have numbered these letters and commented accordingly.

NO. 1 refers to the installation and repair of the water-system in the main cow barn. I have inspected it but, owing to its underground installation, failed to locate the breaks and to tear out the cement floor would be a major and quite expensive job. I therefore suggested that new pipes be installed directly in front of and along the王者 base of the cattle. This is the proper place for such pipes; they are then accessible at all times for inspection, and repair when breaks occur.

The estimate of $250.00, quoted by Mr. James, is much below any estimate that could be given if the floors were taken out. Mr. James is also the only mechanic in this locality available for this type of work. If the institution is to continue under its present set-up, or any other set-up in which the cow barn is to be used, the repair job is not only necessary but very essential in a barn of its type.

NO. 2 - I have inspected the roof of the building referred to and find it in bad condition but not serious. It is an asphalt roof with very little slope. Such roofs are never very satisfactory and fairly constructed are usually, in part, its condition. However, a hen house is a very essential building in the make-up of general farming and the roof of any building is its main protection. By measurement it is 90' by 24', equals 216 sq. ft.; in other words it would need 22 squares of No. 3x6 Cedar Shingles @ $7.60 per sq., equals 2 squares for wastage @ $7.60 per sq., equals 24 squares @ $7.60 equals $182.40 plus 50 lbs. of shingle nails @ 6¢ per lb., $3.00. Approximate cost of material, $185.40.

I suggested to Mr. Soper that if the Department approved of this expenditure, would it not be possible with his farm help and the aid of the older
boy pupils to do the work under an educational project. He thought so. If this building is to remain for any purpose at all, the request should be given consideration.

No. 3 refers to the existing condition of the latrines. Mr. Soper explains, but does not know or suggest an answer to the problem. You will have guessed, of course, that he refers to the outside privies which the pupils are made to use during the day. His letter is disgusting in itself as I feel that such places, especially in the case of this type, should not be left until they are full before emptying. To attempt to remodel or suggest an up-to-date sanitary system for an institution, housing approximately 125 persons, with its present water supply, is a major engineering job; and I would not attempt to discuss the proposition until a competent engineer had explored the possibilities. The letter, however, is submitted as received from Mr. Soper, and as the latrine complained of is not out of order, it being obvious that there is nothing to get out of order. It is merely a matter of cleaning out. There are bathrooms available in the main building at all times for the staff, and night latrines for the pupils. Before I would seriously discuss the matter I would want to know the future plans coupled with an engineer's report.

No. 4 - You must have noticed during your visits to the institution the rusted condition of the steel barn roofs. In this connection, no matter what the future plans are, they should be kept in good repair and to keep such roofs in repair is a paid job. They are badly rusted and favorable consideration should be given. However, you will note by the price quoted that it is a major job and I am not satisfied with one estimate. If you are prepared to consider the request I would suggest that tenders be asked.

No. 5 refers to the overhauling of the Staff refrigerator. I have not inspected this refrigerator but Mr. Soper reports that it is now out of order.

The various jobs are submitted for your consideration. I have endeavoured to cover the items and report accordingly. If favourable to any one, I would suggest that the money allotted be earmarked for each particular job accordingly.

I await your comments with interest.

Geo. W. Down,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dep't of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Memorandum:

Re: Mount Elgin Indian Residential School,
Coradoc Indian Agency - Electoral
District of Kiddleson West,

Indian Agent Down has brought to our attention the rusted condition of the steel barn roofs at this school. Regardless of what the future plans may be for the Mount Elgin School, the Agent feels that the barns should be kept in good repair, as valuable use can be made of them. They are badly rusted at the present time and the only method to improve them would be to paint them. There is approximately 56,000 square feet of painting required. Without being requested to do so, the Principal secured a quotation from Mr. Reid, Brantford, Ont., who offers to supply the material and do the necessary work for an amount of $1,420.00.

I believe that the barn roofs should be preserved, but at the same time it would be preferable to have additional tenders before awarding a contract. I would therefore appreciate it if you would let me know the names of other firms from whom tenders might be secured.

Acting Director.

Dear Sirs,

Attention: Mr. S.K. Seaver

With reference to the writer's recent call on you, we have submitted our report on the condition of your various heating and power units.

DORMITORY BUILDING

A 60 HP Smokeless Portable, LEONARD Firebox Boiler, #23188, which is used for heating the above building, is in relatively good condition, with the exception that on the lower left front between the door opening and rivet seam on the inside of firebox there is some external wasting of the plate which should be built up by welding, or welding on a re-inforcing plate. The extent of this repair cannot be determined until workmen are actually on the job, but we do not believe it would be extensive. This was formerly a wood fired, down draft boiler, under which had been installed a stoker. Usually when a stoker is installed under this type boiler, the upper or water gates are removed by cutting them off and welding the ends. It might be advisable to have this done when the welder is making the other repairs.

Installed, adjacent to this boiler, is a 10 HP Flueless Upright Boiler #34386, which required a new smoke hood which will cost $5.00.

We wish to call your attention to the fact that the roof, or the drain pipe, is leaking and causing considerable rusting of this boiler, which is not a satisfactory condition.

SCHOOL BUILDING

In the basement of the above school is a cast iron Burney-Oxford boiler #70-B, equipped with an Empire Stoker. This boiler is an old round cast iron boiler in very poor condition and not suitable for stoker firing. We recommend that it be replaced by a modern steel boiler.

Yours,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 620H, file 468-5, part 10)
The stoker appeared to be in good condition, but poorly installed; and whether a new boiler is purchased or not, we recommend that a competent stoker man be called in to check on this installation. The automatic control system for the stoker should be re-arranged. A circulating pump would be beneficial on a water job of this size.

We could furnish you with one of our W-130 Leonard-Calor Boilers, built for a working pressure of 150 per square inch, under government Interprovincial Regulations governing boilers of this type, with our usual castings and mountings, as described on page 2 of our catalogue #970-D, for the sum of FIVE HUNDRED AND FIFTY-ONE DOLLARS .........................$551.00 F.O.B. the curb your premises. Government Sales Tax included.

We would place this boiler on a prepared foundation, free access provided, for the sum of THIRTY-THREE DOLLARS .........................$33.00

In the Laundry is installed a 20 H.P. H.R.T. Leonard Boiler. This boiler appeared to be in excellent condition except that the front arch should be replaced. The extent of this work cannot be determined until the workmen are on the job. You also require a new set of wood grates for this boiler, the price of which would be Eighteen Dollars ($18.00), F.O.B. London, Government Sales Tax extra.

We believe the above is a fair picture of the condition of your heating units, and if we can be of any further assistance to you please do not hesitate to get in touch with us.

Yours very truly,

E. LEONARD & SONS LIMITED

October 6th, 1945.

Following your telegram of Tuesday, October 2nd, I immediately contacted Mr. Soper in an endeavour to find out what had happened to the plumbing at the Mt. Elgin Residential School.

After an inspection and discussion with Mr. Soper we decided that nothing could be done in the way of temporary repairs. In fact the system is in perfect working order, only it is being used by impracticable people who do not realize that they are not only wasting water supply and that the spring supply is very limited. For information on the water supply please refer to my report of May 18th, Page 2. However, the present trouble is caused through the excessive use of Toilet Tissue, and insufficient water under pressure. The first is a matter of common sense and education; the second is a matter for an engineering survey. Mr. Soper directed me to install the installation of extra stools but on the flushing of one stool, it took 3 minutes for the flush tank to refill itself; and in another dormitory, 15 minutes. I pointed out, and he agreed, that extra stools is not the answer. One should install a stool for each individual and they would be useless without water. He then suggested chemical closets. My comments on such fixtures for an institution of the kind as the Mt. Elgin Residential School are not printable. However, this is his suggestion and is submitted for your consideration.

I feel that this matter is too complicated, and involves too many questions, to be intelligently discussed by correspondence. Mr. Soper has many other suggestions involving the expenditure of several thousand dollars, and as there is nothing one can do in the way of temporary repairs to the plumbing, I am suggesting a personal discussion. In this connection, and as I have important questions to be discussed with other Branches, I am writing Mr. Hoey, the Director, with reference to a call to Ottawa.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept' of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Bush:

In reply to your request for more detailed information of this school let me say that Mount Elgin has served the Indian people of Ontario for one hundred years.

We now have in residence 105 children, the Government grant is $175.00 per capita. Last year we had one hundred students, giving us an income of $17,500. From this I paid to my staff eleven in all and including my own salary, $10,000 leaving $7,500. From this I had to feed, clothe and light and heat one hundred children for ten months, some of them for twelve months. This means that I have to earn the balance on the farm.

In time past when big boys and big girls came to the school this was possible. Today when we have 45 children under ten and only 3 who are sixteen three fifteen and five thirteen it is an impossibility. I have just paid out over six hundred dollars for repairs to one tractor. These wee children have to earn that. There is no other source from which it can come. If I were to publish that fact some one would be hurt.

Just now we need potato peelers, bread slicers. But we are told that this is impossible. I want to say that something else is impossible. It is impossible for babies of this age to feed, clothe and wash for themselves. I cannot afford to employ help.

The War Assets people have abundance of the things we need and need desperately. But we cannot get
them. We have not the money. But the children need just what can be obtained, and without cost, if we could touch the magic spring.

Children have to go out to the barns to the poultry house, out to do chores but I cannot afford proper protection for them.

We need a dental clinic and a throat clinic. Numbers of these children come from back settlements where medical aid is impossible.

The long winter evenings are coming. We have no games equipment. We need a moving picture projector. Just think of having one hundred and twenty children to amuse seven nights a week for ten months of the year. We need equipment.

After I pay salaries I have just 20 cents a day from the grant to feed and clothe and warm and light the children. On top of that we have to pay all farm equipment repairs and transportation.

I hope that this is something in the line of what you needed.

Yours sincerely,

(sgd.) S. H. Soper

Dear Sir:

I have copy of letter written by Mr. Phillip Phelan, on October 11, with regard to the plumbing and toilet facilities in dormitories in this school, in which letter is a quotation from the communication sent to your department by Mr. G. W. Down. The fact of the matter is that trying to work with the result, we have in residence 75 girls, many of whom are under 10 years of age, and new to the institution. These are all under the supervision of one matron. To say that these are impracticable people is not strictly according to the facts. There are physical limits to the whereabouts of any one person, and no amount of teaching and instruction in the proper use of the toilets will overcome the inadequacy of our water supply. To meet the desperate situation, we have placed ordinary scrub pails in the dormitories for the use of these little children. That may be impracticable, but it is meeting the situation, causing, however, needless work of a very unpleasant character. Now all this may not be printable, but printable or not, it is the fact.

There are a great many things about conditions around this building, and conditions under which little children have to live, which if printed and publicized would cause such a furore of indignation that someone would have to take cognizance of it, and that immediately.

It is impracticable, but also printable that we have here a great number of little children who need attention given to tonsils, adenoids and teeth. We are facing a long winter season, when all of these ills will take their toll of the health of the children, and consequently place an almost impossible burden upon our inadequate staff. I would like some practical suggestions from your department in this matter.

I would also like a clear definition from the Department as to what repairs and equipment may be charged to the Department, and what repairs and equipment must be borne by the labour of 10 and 11 year old boys. In a communication from your department sometime during the summer, I was informed that material for a hay-rack could not be granted by the Department because, forsooth, the wagon upon which the hay rack was to be placed was not the property of the Department. I had to save a crop. Every member of my staff works long hours under most adverse conditions, and the refusal of the Department to even pay for the material to make this hay-rack has brought this whole matter to a head. I wish to say that it is impracticable but it is nevertheless printable, that 6 and 10 year old boys should have to labour in order to pay for equipment to save the harvest.

Dear Mr. [Name],

Your letter of October 15th has been passed on to me for personal consideration and reply.

It is, I feel, unnecessary to state that I appreciate very fully the conditions existing at the Mount Elgin School. These conditions have been to me and, I feel sure, have been to the Secretaries of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church, a source of worry and annoyance ever since I entered the department nine years ago.

You refer in the concluding paragraph of your letter to a thoroughgoing investigation into the relationship between the school management and the Indian Affairs Branch. In this connection, I can only state that a thorough investigation by representatives of the department and a representative of the United Church was held a few years ago. Certain recommendations were made at that time. Inasmuch, however, as the operation of the Mount Elgin Residential School appears to be related to the operation of the Mohawk Institute, it has not been possible for this reason and for a number of others to seriously consider the recommendations made by the members of the Committee of Inquiry. A few weeks ago, we learned that it is the intention of the New England Company of London, England, to send over a representative to study and report upon the future of the Mohawk Institute. It is my hope that immediately following this investigation we shall be in a position to work out a worthwhile educational program based upon the needs of the Indian population of Southwestern Ontario. In the meantime and until such a program is worked out, the operation and administration of the Mount Elgin Institute will require the exercise of the utmost patience and forbearance on the part of departmental officials, the Board of Home Missions of the United Church and the Principal in charge. Dear Mr. Roy:

I have just received your letter of October 26. We have now here in residence 124 children, and there are several more to come. This places a great responsibility upon our physical and spiritual resources. We are indeed glad to have so many little folk, and I am convinced that my present staff has the qualifications of character and ability needed to cope with the present situation. I am indeed fortunate to have such an exceptional group of fine people in the school. Nothing but the good hand of God upon us could have brought together such a group with such fine qualities as they have. It will take time, and a great deal of patience to develop in these little folk the qualities and abilities needed to fit them for life after they leave school.

From my short experience with the people of the various reserves, served by this school, I am convinced that they have confidence in the staff of the school, and in spite of other attractions and advantages, they are continuing to send to us such large numbers of small ones.

I want to thank you once again for your continued and deep interest in us, and I wish to assure you that now that I am assured that this school has a large place in your plans for the future, we will do all in our power to keep the buildings and equipment in such condition as will tide us over the present emergency.

We desperately need additional members on our staff, in order to keep up with the needs of so many little children, and I hope that within the very near future, ways and means will be found to enable us to have such an increased staff.

I will be glad to co-operate in any way possible to bring about any improvement that is possible in the present situation.

I remain

Yours very sincerely,

Ottawa, November 14, 1948.

It is my understanding that accompanied by Mr. Arneil you will visit the Mount Pleasant Institute on or about Thursday, November 28th.

Yesterday, I had an opportunity to discuss somewhat hurriedly with Doctor Dorey not only the condition of the residential school itself, but steps that might be taken to provide reasonably up-to-date educational facilities for the Indians of the Cariboo Agency. Doctor Dorey feels, and I agree with him, that the department has at its disposal sufficient information to decide on a definite policy and that in fairness to the Church authorities this policy should be clearly outlined and submitted to the Church at the earliest possible date. He and I are both agreed that it would be a sheer waste of public funds to undertake extensive or substantial repairs to the present building.

In view of all the circumstances, I am recommending to the Minister that a four-room consolidated school, together with a principal's residence, be built at this Agency just as soon as funds for this purpose can be provided. The new school, in my judgment, should cease to operate at the end of the present school year, June 30th, and that only the repairs necessary for the comfort of the principal and the staff should be undertaken at this time.

It is just possible that a shortage of skilled labour and an equally acute shortage of lumber and other building materials may prevent the erection of the school we have in mind at this time.
in mind at any time during the next fiscal year. If the school is not built, provision will have to be made for the care of a number of orphan children and children from disrupted and broken homes now enrolled at the institutions. Indeed, this provision will have to be made in any case. This provision can only be made after a careful survey of the Indian homes at the Agency has been undertaken and perhaps a survey of Indian homes at various and other points from which pupils are recruited. Doctor Loney and I feel that with a small Government grant, plus the monthly allowances for which provision is made in the Family Allowance Act, little difficulty should be experienced in securing suitable homes for orphan children.

You will have to discuss these and other relevant matters with Doctor Loney, who will also visit Munsey on the 23rd instant. A great deal of consideration will have to be given to the type of school necessary to meet the needs of the Indians. The selection of a site and the availability of a dependable water supply are matters of utmost importance. It is just possible that after your visit you may recommend that an additional educational survey may have to be undertaken at the Agency to work out a well-balanced educational program. The condition of the reserve roads is a matter that might be discussed with the Agent in view of the fact that transportation facilities will have to be provided if a consolidated school is established.

Doctor Loney was of the opinion that the management of the program we have in mind might be withheld from the Indians for the time being at least. I am not at all sure that we can successfully do this; however, this is a matter you can discuss with him at the time of your visit.

I am sending a copy of this memorandum to Doctor Loney for his information.

IMPORTANT—Caution Notice
PLEASE READ CAREFULLY

School Desks

ACCEPTANCE OF SHIPMENT AND BREAKAGE

The goods covered by the attached invoice were received by the Railroad Company as having been received by them in good condition and properly packed. Before accepting the shipment from the Railroad Company, the consignee should make sure that all articles enumerated on the bill of lading are included in the shipment and in good condition. To protect yourself against loss or damage in transit, check the shipment carefully with your bill of lading, noting the number of crates or packages in their condition. Any parts broken by the Railroad Company will be duplicated at our expense.

First—The consignee must not give the Railroad Company a clear receipt for the complete shipment if there is any shortage, breakage or damage of any kind. In the event there is any shortage, breakage or damage of the goods delivered, the consignee can give a receipt for the goods if the railroad agent will make a notation on the freight bill indicating the amount of the shortage or the extent and nature of the damage. This freight bill must be mailed to us.

If the breakage or damage is concealed and not discovered until the goods are unpacked, notify the agent of the Railroad Company by letter or telephone to call immediately and examine the shipment. The carrier is equally responsible for "Concealed Damage" as for visible damage and when notified as suggested it places the burden of proof upon the carrier. When you have given the Railroad Company notice in the manner suggested, mail us your bill of lading and paid freight bill.

Second—When there is shortage, breakage or damage in an express shipment, request your Express Agent to furnish you receipt showing the condition in which the shipment was delivered to you.

Third—When you report shortage or breakage to us, enumerate fully and describe clearly the parts you desire replaced. In ordering standards for School Desks specify size and whether right or left, which is always determined as you sit at the desk. It is well to supplement your order by mentioning the pattern mark you will find on the pieces. If several styles of desks, be sure to specify the style for which the parts are desired, particularly if wooden parts are being ordered. Care in making your order clear and complete will permit us to give you immediate service.

Fourth—All claims for shortage, breakage or damage must be made within Thirty Days and you must provide us with the necessary papers to enable us to file claim against the Railroad or Express Company, as explained in Paragraphs No. 1 and No. 2. Otherwise claim will not be allowed.

Fifth—We are not responsible for parts broken through carelessness of drayman hauling the goods or your workmen in assembling and installing.

STORAGE

The desks manufactured under this contract were constructed from thoroughly air seasoned and properly kiln-dried material and were in perfect condition when shipment left our factory. They were stored under conditions that permitted no variation regarding local atmospheric conditions. Under no condition store this furniture even temporarily in a damp room or basement nor in a partly completed structure where building material, such as plaster, calcimine, paint, etc., may be thrown over the crates. Store in a cool, well ventilated room of normal uniform temperature. The crates containing woods should rest on their ends and all crates and boxes be elevated above floor a few inches to allow free air circulation under and around them.

CLEANING AND POLISHING

Do not attempt to clean or polish the woodwork with linseed oil, turpentine, undiluted benzine, gasoline, alcohol, or anything of that kind. These materials are varnish solvents which will remove the finish from the wood; nor do we recommend any one of the various furniture polishes on the market. The following is a very good cleaner and polish, the constituents of which can usually be obtained in any paint or drug store for a few cents:

3 parts New England Oil
1 part Benzine.

Mix thoroughly before using.

Moisten a rag with this solution, apply sparingly to the surface and immediately rub dry with a clean dry cloth. Cheesecloth is recommended. The most effective result is obtained through the rubbing, not through excessive use of the solution.
