Ottawa, May 30th, 1946.

Mr. Roey

Re: Mount Elgin School.

When visiting the Caradoc Agency on the 22nd and 23rd of May, Mr. Arneil, Indian Agent Downs, and myself, discussed what should be done with the present Mount Elgin School, when the new school is completed.

Mr. Downs suggested that we should remove the two top floors, leaving the ground floor of the building and use this partly for a recreational centre for the Indians, the balance for meetings of home makers clubs, etc.

My own opinion is, it would be a very expensive proposition to carry out Mr. Down's suggestion, and when the work is completed, we would only have an old building, very difficult to heat, and likely, almost impossible to keep clean.

Mr. Down has already had inquiries from wrecking firms wishing to quote a price on tearing down the building.

I feel very definitely that when the new school is completed, the old school should be demolished.

No doubt, a recreation centre for the Indians would be very advisable, and possibly it should be located on the site of the present Mount Elgin School, but I believe that a new building erected for this purpose would not cost as much as it would to endeavour to renovate the present building and would be much more satisfactory.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Memorandum:

Mr. HOMT,

Inspector Arnell and I visited the Caradoc Agency on May 22 and 23, in connection with the proposed erection of a new four-room day school, to replace the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School.

There are two sites available - one in the village of Nuneys and the other on the property formerly occupied by the Mount Elgin Residential School. We favour the latter site because there is an excellent location available and, in addition, we have an opportunity for teaching agricultural subjects to the pupils.

The only difficulty with this site is that the road from Nuneys to the new site is reported to be in very bad condition at certain periods of the year. The road is one mile long and it may be necessary to put it in condition to be used at all periods of the year. However, this work will be necessary, as we expect to be driving the children to the new school and, consequently, a year around road will be required.

We interviewed Mr. T. S. Caldwell, District Engineer, Ontario Highways Department, London, with a view to obtaining some assistance from the Provincial Government. Mr. Caldwell promised to inspect the road and let us have an estimate of what it would cost to put it into proper condition. When visiting Mr. Caldwell, we also met Mr. Marshall, Chief Engineer, Ontario Highways Department, and Mr. Marshall instructed Mr. Caldwell to forward his report to him so that a decision might be made regarding what portion of the cost could be met by the Ontario Highways.

With reference to the erection of the new school, Inspector Arnell obtained the following information:

(a) Foundation - Graham and Graham, London, Ontario, are prepared to shovel out the excavation in three days' time. They will require 2 weeks' notice before we desire to have the work completed.

(b) Building Foreman - Charles Lady, Builder, Rodney, Ont., is available. He has an excellent reputation as a builder and his services can be secured within the next two weeks. He has built many homes and one church at Rodney. He can read blue prints and take full charge. Indian helpers, many of whom are competent carpenters, are available, as well as other Indian labour.

(c) Material - This can likely be secured within two months' time. It may be necessary to apply to the Timber Controller for priority. Arrangements were made with a qualified man to prepare a list of the materials and forward this to the Department by June 1.

In view of the above information, secured by Mr.
Arnold, I would appreciate it if we could receive permission to proceed. The sooner we start purchasing the material, the sooner we can commence building.

I might also mention that both Indian Agent Down and the newly appointed farm instructor have had considerable experience in erecting buildings and will be in a position to supervise the erection of the school and keep the Department fully informed.

Philip Maclean,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, May 30, 1946.

Attention Col. Neary:

With regard to the installing of the water in the school class rooms and the apartments in the old school building of the Mt. Elgin Institute, I have been running into difficulties; difficulties which should, and could, have been avoided if only persons would do their work and not meddle with other people's.

I am annoyed and have reason to be when my work is troubled and I have to go begging for workmen because of a suggested change of plans which, by the way, had to be discarded. I have been quite concerned and it is only by grace and the very mild weather that saved us from what could have developed into a disastrous break of the entire system, and a major repair job which could have closed the entire building. The plumber attributes any delay caused to a change from the original plan, which we had both gone into very thoroughly and he is very definite in advising that he is not waiting on any
person, which includes the Government, when they do not know what they want. Even the pipes, which were mentioned, are black pipes and cannot be used for underground work. However, after many attempts, by telephone and personal contact, I have been able to smooth out the differences and I have the plumber on the job and have advised him to proceed in his best workmanship manner and take instructions only from my Office which I feel was your intention when you were here.

Yours truly,

Dec. 13, 1946.

I wish to acknowledge your letter of November 30th with regard to boilers at the recently closed Mt. Elgin School.

Inspection reveals two boilers, one of very large capacity capable of heating the entire main building; the other of much smaller capacity used in the laundry. Both units are built in and supplied by the Leonard Boiler Company, of London, Ontario, but neither have the capacity rating or number stamped in. Both, I believe, are in need of repairs but, owing to the fact that the Leonard Boiler Company is a big concern in London, the repair problem would not create difficulty and, providing the cost of dismantling, trucking and reinstalling were not too high, the smaller of the two might take care of Rev. Zimmerman's proposition.

I have been in contact with Col. Randle and discussed the matter with him. I have also written the Leonard Boiler Company with a view of ascertaining the capacity which, if available, I will forward to him. As far as I am aware, in the present set up of things at the Caradoc agency, we have no use for either unit; and if the Rev. Mr.
Zimmerman can arrange for dismantling and haulage at costs less than a new small auxiliary boiler which, I understand, is his requirement; I think that it can well be transferred.

I wish you would keep this question in mind so that we can discuss it further at the coming conference in Toronto.

Yours truly,

Geo. W. Down,

To the Honorable

The Dept. Supt. Genl. of I. Affairs,

Ottawa.

Sir:

I wish to draw your attention to two or three matters touching the Insurance of this establishment. As you have by the $2,500 recently paid the Mission Rooms on account of extras on this New building made the Department the owner of all. Would it not be wise for you to increase the amount of Insurance and include these extras. You have the cost of each item. I judge that what is called a Blanket insurance would be the best covering the building and fittings, but not the furnishings which are still the property of the Missionary Society and we will keep a risk on all furnishings till such time as the Department may take possession of all.

Now about the old building. I understand the Department has a right to it still, but having vacated it as we have, unless some arrangement is made with the company in the event of fire the risk of loss will be valid.

We use the old building for storage of roots, fruit, meat and the pupil's personal clothing.

For the purpose of the reconstruction of said building, which will be an item on the Report, I have now with something in preparation about the same as stated above.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:-

Re: Toronto Casualty F. & M. Ins. Co.

In furtherance of my letter of the 21st ult., acknowledging your letter of the 20th ult., I have inquired the particulars of this transaction and had the privilege of reviewing the correspondence file of the Company.

I do not think this a proper case for interference by this Department. The one and only question appears to be "Was the insurance in question validly cancelled pursuant to the statutory conditions, by the registered notice of termination dated June 20th 1923?" The condition of the policy in force at that date read as follows:

(R.S.C.1914,c.163,S.194)

"(11) The insurance may be terminated by the company by giving seven days' notice to that effect, and, if on the cash plan, by tendering therewith a rateable proportion of the premium paid, for the unexpired term, calculated from the termination of the notice, and the policy shall cease after such notice, or notice and tender as the case may be, and the expiration of the seven days."

"(15) Any written notice to the assured may be by letter delivered to the assured or by registered letter addressed to him at his last post office address notified to the company, or where no address is notified and the address is not known, addressed to him at the post office of the agency, if any, from which the application was received."
The written notice intended to be in compliance with the above recited terms of the policy, was addressed to you as follows:- Superintendent General of Indian Affairs for Canada, Mount Elgin Industrial Farm, Township of Caradoc County of Middlesex. This address will appear to be defective in that your address is not at the Mount Elgin Industrial Farm, which circumstance is confirmed by your failure to receive the written notice.

If a loss had occurred between June 1923 and the expiration of the policy in 1926, you would have thought you were insured and I should think the company would have had considerable difficulty denying the liability. Under these circumstances, if you are prepared to admit that you were in fact insured, you can have no possible claim for the refund of premium. It now seems difficult under the circumstances as I have them before me, for you to urge that the company make a refund on premium because it thought the insurance had terminated. The important question is again "Was the insurance validly terminated?"

I should appreciate learning your reaction to my expression of opinion, although in any event I suppose the matter is one for the courts and not for this Department.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Memorandum:

The Auditor General has written with reference to the payment of insurance premiums on the Mt. Elmo Indian Residential School. He asks if this institution is in the property of the Crown and if so, why the insurance. Further, he enquires if the school does not belong to the Crown, what is the authority for making payment (I presume he means from Parliamentary Appropriation).

I believe that the protection of the Band's equity in this school should be provided from Band Funds. However, as the Band's equity is now only a small part of the value of the building—say 10 or 15 per cent. of this equity may have disappeared by depreciation, I wish to recommend that the insurance be discontinued.

In 1896, when the present building was erected, various Indian bands that are served by the Band contributed $19,000 from their funds toward the capital expense. Since that time and including the fiscal year 1930-31, the Department has expended from Parliamentary Appropriation, for minor improvements, a total of approximately $346,300. In 1915, fire destroyed most of the outbuildings, and, assuming the collection of insurance, $7,400 was repaid to the Band Funds, leaving their equity at $11,600. Insurance to the extent of $12,000 has been carried since that time.

The present policies expire in February and March, 1935. By this time, the Indian bands interested will have enjoyed educational facilities for 39 years, and their share in the building, because of depreciation, will really have disappeared. I restate my recommendation that the insurance be not renewed when it next expires. Twelve bands are interested, as shown on the attached list of January 2, 1932.

Memorandum:

Supt. of Welfare and Training

Re: New four-room Indian Day School,
Caradoc Agency.

As instructed, I spent Wednesday and Thursday, June 19 and 20, on the Caradoc reserve in connection with the above. Indian Agent Down and Mr. Charles Ludy, Rodney, Ontario, whom Mr. Armitage chose as foreman for the work, met me in London. We immediately proceeded to the reserve and decided on the position or the new building. It will be built directly in front of the old residential school. It is a splendid site, being high, and we should have no trouble with drainage.

In conversation with the Indian Agent and Mr. Ludy, who had previously reviewed the plans and specifications, I found that it would be impossible to secure the amount of lumber that we would require. Under these circumstances, we reviewed the plans and specifications again and made certain changes which would permit construction to proceed immediately.

As a result of this discussion it was decided to make the following changes:

1. General construction - It was decided to use cinder blocks above the concrete foundation.

2. Cinder blocks will be used for interior partitions in the basement.

3. Masonite, 4 ft. high, will be used on the interior sides of the classrooms.

4. The entrance door to the main floor and also the entrance door to the basement will be widened to 6 ft.

We then proceeded to various places in the immediate vicinity of the reserve, with a view to securing the materials that we needed and to make arrangements for white labour required. This resulted in the following arrangements being fully completed:

1. Graham and Graham, Balmoral Road, London, Ontario, will dig the foundation during the week of July 1. The cost will be $5 per cubic yard and an additional charge of $2.50 an hour for the trucks to cart the excavated earth from the site.

2. Two hundred and forty (240) bbls. of cement were ordered from Mr. Pardy, Moosie Bridges, Ontario. This was the only firm that was in a position to supply the cement within a reasonable time. Mr. Pardy definitely promised that the cement...
would be delivered on the site by July 3. Indian Agent Down stated that he had done business with Mr. Fardy previously and found him a very reliable man.

3. The gravel for use in the cement work has been secured from Mr. Mahler, Delaware, Ontario. He will deliver the gravel from the gravel pit to the site or the school at $1.50 a cubic yard. This price includes the cost of the gravel and trucking same a distance of 8 miles. This is the closest gravel pit to the reserve.

4. The cinder blocks were ordered from Elgin Concrete Products (David Winter, President), 324 Talbot Street, St. Thomas, Ontario. Each block is 8 x 8 x 16 and will be delivered for 2s cents each, f.o.b., the site of the school.

5. Fennel Brothers, Newbury, with whom the Department has done business for many years and who are a very reliable firm, will supply most of the lumber that is required. This was also the first in that part of the country that would promise to do so. There may be some of the lumber that even they cannot supply but it will have to be secured wherever available.

6. Indian Agent Down is making arrangements for the cement mixer and a competent man to operate it. The other labour required in this regard will be secured by employing Indians.

7. As suggested by Inspector Arnell, I interviewed Mr. D. D. Crawford, Delaware, with reference to securing carpenters and brick-layers as required. I went to Mr. Brydges but was unable to find Mr. Ed. Bateman as he was not at home. However, I told Mr. Crawford to mention the matter to Mr. Bateman so that he might be able to assist some names if he desired. Mr. Crawford was not aware of any tradesmen of this type who were unemployed at the present time but said he would make enquiries and advise Mr. Down. In the event of Mr. Crawford not being able to suggest any competent workmen, I feel that we will have to leave the matter to the foreman, Charles Ludy and to the Indian Agent.

8. I recommend that Indian Agent Down be authorized to purchase the hardware, nails, etc., when and where available. These items are also in short supply and it will probably be necessary to go to several stores before obtaining the quantity needed.

9. Later on, it will be necessary to have an electrical contractor submit a quotation on wiring the school. Electrical current is available as heavy wires have been connected with the former residential school.

10. At the suggestion of Mr. Ludy, the foreman, it was decided that the services of a surveyor would be needed for an hour or so, to properly lay out the site. Authority was given for employing Mr. John Findlay, St. Thomas, Ontario, to do this work, as St. Thomas is only a few miles from the reserve.
11. As previously stated, Mr. Charles Ludy was selected as foreman by Mr. Arnell. Mr. Ludy has had considerable experience in the erection of buildings and I think will be a very capable foreman. We have not yet settled with him regarding his salary but I recommend that we offer him ten dollars ($10.00) a day.

12. Indian labour will be used as much as possible. There are one or two efficient Indian carpenters on the reserve and of course they will be employed. As pointed out above, arrangements have also been made for securing any white labour that may be necessary.

13. Before leaving I had another long discussion with both Mr. Ludy and Indian Agent. Both of them are fully aware of all the commitments that were made and I am sure that Mr. Lown will co-operate to the fullest possible extent with Mr. Ludy. As you will note from the above, the basement will be excavated during the week of July 1. The gravel and cement will be on the site by that time and Mr. Ludy will be able to start the actual work immediately. The firm supplying the cinder blocks is manufacturing them in St. Thomas and will supply them as required. Fennel Brothers promised to have the lumber delivered by July 15. Of course, there may be some delay in securing some of the longer pieces required for the roof, but these will not be needed for some time.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Re: Road from Village to Mount Elgin Residential School, site chosen for new Caradoc School.

With reference to the construction of the above road I would say that approval has not yet been secured for the expenditure of the funds required to construct this road, but we are asking that an item be placed in the Supplementary Estimates and that until the Supplementary Estimates are passed that we be permitted to use funds from the main estimates in order that this work may be commenced. When the approval is secured I shall get in touch with you further.

In the meantime, a discussion took place yesterday with officers of the Department of Reconstruction, and we were informed that any project amounting to more than $5,000 had to be first approved by Reconstruction Department if it had not been included in our main estimates. The means of seeking this approval is to file with Reconstruction a form which that department supplies, known as Schedule A, to which must be attached two copies of the plans and specifications of the project. These plans and specifications must be full detailed plans and specifications on which tenders could be called and a contract awarded.

Would it be possible for you to arrange with Mr. Caldwell, the Municipal District Engineer, to prepare these plans and specifications on the basis on which he has submitted his estimate. The concrete culvert which has to be built on the road is part of the project, and is estimated to cost $3,600.00. Could Mr. Caldwell furnish us with a plan of a concrete culvert that could be erected, also a specification. No doubt the Provincial Department of Highways have plans and specifications which would apply both to the road and bridge.
Should you be unable to secure the plans and specifications from the District Municipal Engineer or other official of the Provincial Government, it will be necessary for the department to have plans and specifications prepared by officers of the Surveys and Engineering Branch. That branch has already a full quota of work to be done, and there will probably be considerable delay in securing the plans from that branch, which will, of necessity, delay the whole project.

I am, as explained to you in the opening paragraph of this letter, writing this letter to you before securing the authority for the expenditure as I am hopeful that the matter will be favourably considered. However, should it have to be delayed until next year the plans and specifications will be required and the schedule will have to be filed with the Department of Reconstruction before any money can be allotted to us for the work. I trust, therefore, that you will be able to forward the plans and specifications at an early date.

Director.

Dear Mr. Down,

There are several matters which I should like to bring to the attention of the Welfare and Training Division, through you, for clarification and approval.

Inasmuch as the large building is now vacant, I would request that the telephone be moved over to the old building for the use of the Principal and staff during the coming year. It is my hope that the Department will see fit to provide the telephone for our use, with the understanding that all extra charges for long distance calls be paid for by the individual sender.

The old building, which now includes the Principal's apartment, his office, three classrooms, four staff rooms and bathroom, as well as the apartment being used by Mr. Bush, an employee of the Department, is supplied with its water from a pump in the main building. It seems reasonable and essential to continue such hydro and water supply as is necessary to operate the old classroom building, and I hope that the authorities will reconsider their purpose to cut off these connections at the end of July. Very little would be needed to make this building electrically independent, the two apartments being on separate meters already. The water supply will need some alteration before the freeze-up.

With respect to educational facilities for the coming term, I would recommend that classes be not dependent upon the completion of the new school but that they be begun in the classrooms already available here at the time agreed upon for the term's work. I would hope for some direction in the near future as to whether I am to have the privilege and responsibility of securing additional teachers, or whether they will be chosen by the Department upon my recommendation as to our needs.

All of which is respectfully submitted by

E.E.M. Joblin,
Director of Education.

Re: New Indian Day School, Caradoc

You will be interested to learn of the progress made to date in the building of the above mentioned school. I therefore feel that a short report is in order.

To get things running smoothly on any building project it involves unforeseen and sometimes annoying difficulties, and this particular undertaking is no exception. In digging the footing foundations they encountered about 3 feet of water on a blue clay bottom. I was immediately consulted and from now on it would appear that I am Indian Agent, Building Consultant, Farm Instructor and General Fixer. Quite a series of titles but what's in a name? The work interests me; everything around me is its either has to go or bog down; and the only bogging down that I will permit in this particular school building is a material short supply. To take care of the water problem I was able to obtain sufficient field tile, and had the Indian labourers dig a deep trench leading to the river bank where we took our first footing. But, to change to say, our next problem was water; but water we wanted, not water we wanted to dispose of. It was necessary in mixing cement for the footings. Several unsuccessful attempts were tried, and eventually I secured a small gasoline engine with rotary pump attached, and then began to dig out the main water line from the spring. This is located, and had a plumber tap into it and install the pumping unit on the ground surface. Presto! All the water we need to complete the building operations, and perhaps supply the school with a close at hand efficient water system. After this foundation work were ready to pour cement footings but, alas! a large-size cement mixer was out at another job and was not available but,—the show must go on. I immediately had the Agency small mixer taken to the site and presto! once again, we were operating.

I have just left the site and am able to report everything running like a clock and, without further mishap, the entire footing foundation, 250', will be poured by Thursday noon. We will then be ready to commence building and placing the cribbing for the basement walls.
For this we have everything on hand with the exception of a few pieces of 2x4 lumber, and nails. For these two items I am now securing the country.

I have accepted my new job of Building Consultant philosophically, and will tender my account at a later date! In the meantime am taking a few days vacation but will be back on the job by the 16th of September when I hope to see the cribbing built and ready for pouring the walls. I shall then start my rounds again for the necessary materials, and bricklayers.

In conclusion, I am very pleased with the progress to date and can assure you that everything is being done, and will be done, to keep things moving.

Geo. W. Down,

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

School bus for Caradoc Indian Agency

Use of Vehicle

This vehicle, a Ford 1½ ton ambulance, is intended for use as a school bus at the Mount Elgin Indian Day School, near Muncey, Ontario. The branch has closed down the residential school at this place and is now building a four-room consolidated school for junior and senior high grades and for auxiliary training classes. This consolidation will involve the bringing of the children for distances up to 6 miles. This will not only relieve the load on the badly overcrowded elementary schools but will also eliminate the payment of tuition grants now being paid to have these children attend provincial schools. We are going to use the old buildings of the residential school while awaiting the completion of the new school. We are now all ready to begin classes but lack a bus.

On August 18 a letter was sent to our Assets Corporation Head Office in Montreal, requesting information regarding the availability of two personnel carriers. The use of these vehicles was recommended by the Provincial Inspectors of Schools in the Strathroy area, whose school records were purchasing ten of them from General Motors dealers. On August 27 we again wrote our Assets Corporation in Toronto as our original letter had been referred there. On September 7 an answer was received, which read:

"At the present time we have no available surplus from which your requirements can be met. However, if such type of..."
vehicle should become available shortly in which case they will be offered to you".

One of the branch officials visited the Cariboo Agency and learned through the Provincial School Inspector that Middlesex Motors were expecting vehicles in which would be suitable for school bus purposes. Actually this ambulance which is now available is a much better type of vehicle for a school bus than a personnel carrier for the following reasons:

(1) It has a much larger carrying capacity (replaces two personnel carriers required).

(2) It is a safer vehicle due to its all steel body.

(3) It is a warmer vehicle (the personnel carrier's windows are only made of transparent plastic).

Since the request to purchase this ambulance was forwarded, our Assets Corporation have informed us that a used personnel carrier was available. However, this was only one vehicle of the two required and could have only provided transportation for some ten children. Due to time lapse, this vehicle can not now be purchased as our Assets have to be advised of acceptance within 10 days.

Now a month and a half of the school term has passed and these children still have no adequate transportation.

Transportation Policy

The trend in modern education is towards consolidated schools and away from the one-room school. In line with this provision of a broader and more adequate education the Branch has begun a series of school consolidations. Elsewhere, such as at St. Catherine's Indian Day School at Duncan, B.C.; Fisher River Day Schools, Manitoba; Saguenay, Que., and some dozen other places, it has been possible to provide transportation by contract with local bus operators. However, this has not been possible at Cariboo due to the fact that there is a large consolidation being carried out by local provincial school...
authorities. The Superintendent of Welfare and Training, the Inspector of Indian Agencies for Ontario, the Indian Agent and the Supervising Principal of the Caradoc Indian Schools met with Provincial Inspectors of Schools Gordon Young and H. Smith to discuss this situation. As previously pointed out, the local School Boards are purchasing used army personnel carriers, ambulances, etc., from local dealers as they have been unable to get local bus operators to contract for school transportation. They assured us there was no hope of getting such a contract for our school.

Another deciding factor was the poor roads in the Agency. During the winter there will be a dearth of snow clearing equipment, we have not been able to purchase the snow plow required. Therefore the Army Type 4 wheel drive vehicle will be able to provide transportation where a normal 2 wheel drive vehicle would fail.

There is then an urgent necessity for this vehicle. The purchase from a local dealer was requested only after car assets possibilities had been examined thoroughly. The school is ready; the pupils are ready; the teachers are ready—all that is lacking is transportation for those living over 3 miles from the school.

Dictated by Col. Murray

Nov. 6, 1948.

I wish to refer to your letter of November last with regard to the Normal Training Building at the former Mt. Elgin Residential School, which I find difficult to understand. Mr. Joblin did not relinquish control of anything and at all times he had full control of all buildings. I have never had charge and therefore have nothing to hand over and since Mr. Joblin advised me that the machinery did not belong to the Department of Indian Affairs, but to the United Church of Canada, and that he has been advised accordingly, I therefore took it as a polite request to leave things alone.

There is such a thing as being loyal to one's employer, but I do not wish to enter into any acrimonious discussion or correspondence with officials of the United Church. In any case, Mr. Joblin will be advised of the contents of your letter without delay and any machinery or a motor, which was suggested missing during your visit and is being used by Mr. Joblin in connection with the building of the new school, will be returned immediately.

With regard to the old school laundry, I do not know who made the suggestion, but I am definitely not interested in any workshop that is not under our personal supervision and control and I certainly will not be told that the machinery therein does not belong to us. After recent events I am more than ever convinced that I want no part in establishing such a workshop in the buildings of the old Mt. Elgin School.

If you wish to establish a suitable shop for repairing farm machinery, I have a building in the setup of Agency buildings and I'll need whatever pieces of machinery and if you are prepared to finance the proposition, I will submit a list of what is necessary. If not, I must carry on in the old inefficient way, but there is one thing I must point out. I cannot longer undertake to repair this old farm machinery that is returning under our fast depleting Welfare revolving account. While
I am on this question I must point out that before the Spring of 1947, and well in advance of seeding, the entire question of individual Indian farming under a Farm Instructor and the farming of the old Mt. Elgin lands must be discussed and practical working arrangements made.

Yours Truly,

Geo. W. Down,
INDIAN AGENT.

Dept' of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Nov. 26, 1946.

Further to my letter of November 22, wherein I stated that we had been running into difficulties in the building of the Caradoc Indian Continuation School. Mr. Mahler and I were very much concerned and did not know where to attach the blame. I therefore had a check of materials made, also a general perusal of the blue prints and it was not until a check was made with Fennell and Son, the firm supplying the manufactured merchandise, that I discovered the mistake and that the Surveys and Engineering Branch of the Department of Mines & Resources is directly responsible.

It was revealed that two separate plans had been submitted. Plan No. 1 under date of April, 1943, and Plan No. 2 under date of February, 1945. Compare these plans and you will discover that there are many differences such as windows, elevations, joist material etc. The bill of material was ordered under Plan No. 1 and the building was proceeding under plan No. 2. Under the circumstances I had to discard one plan, and owing to the fact that the building was proceeding under No. 2, No. 1 was discarded. I also ordered Mr. Fennell to discontinue manufacture of material.
accordingly. We are now off on the right foot but I think the matter of a building is important enough to register a complaint of carelessness against officials of the Surveys and Engineering Branch. I am extremely busy and have had to give a great deal of my time in straightening the matter out.

You will be interested to learn that the basement is complete with window sashes placed and we are taking advantage of the mild weather in laying the cement blocks dividing the various basement rooms, which when finished, leaves everything in readiness for the upper structure.

Yours truly,

Geo. W. Down,
INDIAN AGENT.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attention Mr. Phelan

I wish to refer to the new school under construction at the Caradoc Agency and to advise that there is a balance on hand from Advance Cheque No. 086703 to pay labour costs. Owing to the joist timber shortage, which is the major hold up, it does not appear that I am going to be able to use this amount before March 31, the end of the present fiscal year. Mr. G.W. Down, Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ontario,

We would appreciate receiving a report regarding the new school in your Agency. Have you obtained the materials required to complete the building? Is labour available? We are anxious to have this building completed as soon as possible.

You might advise what accountable advance you will require.

[Signature]

Bernard Neary,

Muncey, Ontario,
May 2, 1947.

New School Building Operations
Garadoc Agency

You will recall that late in 1946 building operations, owing to inability to obtain the necessary joist material, ceased. Since then I have maintained a regular contact with various lumber merchants in the hope of securing the necessary material. The situation is still difficult and likely to remain so. However, I have been promised favorable consideration in shipments which might arrive in the near future. Quite recently I learned of some second hand steel beams salvaged from a bridge in the city of London which the contractor promised me first consideration. We could use some of this material to advantage and I am wondering what your reaction to purchasing our requirements would be. It can be purchased for approximately four and one half or five cents a pound, F.O.B. Muncey, which is considerably below cost to say nothing of the F.O.B. point.

I spoke to Mr. Arneil about it and asked him to mention it to you. Personally, I think it is a good buy and might be the means of getting building operations started again. What do you suggest? My other thought is that I am to proceed with arrangements as made in the fiscal year of 1946, namely, to go ahead with the purchase of necessary material, also hire and pay men on an hourly
basis with the foreman based at $10.00 a day. In other words material cost and labour basis. If so please forward an accountable advance sufficient to pay labour as we progress.

Last year, $4,000.00 was provided but an unexpended balance of $1,409.93 was returned to the Receiver General at the end of the 1946-47 fiscal year.

Yours truly,

Geo. W. Down,

Hail the Stork!

Yes, that great bird which has been circling overhead for some thirty days has finally made a perfect three-point landing.

Here is the parcel which he delivered, the first edition of Reo Safety School Bus News. We hope you'll like it.

Now that we've brought the child into being, however, the job of supporting it is yours as well as our own. That responsibility we cheerfully pass on to you.

But, seriously, the Reo Safety School Bus News is your publication. Please consider it as such and use it as such. We need your wholehearted support in making a GO of this publication. Send photos, suggestions, ideas—material right off the firing line. Let's pool our knowledge and experience and put this over with a bang.

We hope you will enjoy this first issue of the Reo Safety School Bus News, which we plan to make more interesting, informative and colorful with each succeeding issue.

Meantime, don't forget, send your comments and suggestions to Reo Motors, Inc., School Bus Division, Lansing 20, Mich.

Full Steam Ahead!

A year after War's end finds schools throughout the country in almost desperate need of new and safe transportation equipment.

A year after War's end finds widespread public understanding of "Safety" and a willingness to finance "Safe" School Transportation. Money is available. States have accumulated an estimated $1 billion dollars, which is now reflected in State aid to schools.

Now, beginning in 1947, Reo can, and will, produce complete Safety School Buses in volume to meet the rapidly growing and definitely urgent need for real modern, safe school transportation equipment.

The problem of building and equipping a plant in 1946 was a big one. We did it however—and are now ready to proceed full steam ahead.
Home of Reo Safety School Bus Bodies is situated in the center of New York State, midway between Syracuse and Utica, New York on the main line of the New York Central railroad. The plant has over 250,000 square feet of floor space under cover and is equipped with the latest modern machinery to produce all-steel Reo Safety School bus bodies. The new final assembly building 450 feet long and 120 feet wide, does not have a post in the building and has the very latest in modern equipment for the assembly of bodies, including four moving assembly lines and infra red light paint drying ovens. Capable executive personnel, plus a force of specially trained workers, provides that great wealth of experience and ability which has, and will continue to contribute so much to the history of advanced body design in the field of school bus transportation.
The National School Administering Convention will be held in Atlantic City, New Jersey, from March 4 through March 6, 1947. School administrators are invited to attend. The keynote will be delivered by Dr. J. W. Reo. This will be an unusual opportunity for educators to meet and discuss current educational issues.

CONSTRUCTION

Body is entirely of all steel construction of sufficient strength to support bus resting on the side or in an inverted position without showing signs of weakness or collapse.

Fuselage sections of 16 gauge steel body roof bows (roof supports) are continuous from body post to body post and are welded on both sides to a 14 gauge longitudinal roof rail, which in turn is welded to body post. Roof bows and body post are set on 27 inch centers.

All material used in body construction are thoroughly cleaned of welding slag, grease and other foreign matter and then are treated for rust prevention with red or brown oxide primer.

Concealed surfaces of inner and outer panels which forms a dead air space are covered with low thermal conductivity insulation, protection against heat, cold and noise.

Wheelhousing is constructed from 16 gauge steel with inside top edge rounded eliminating all sharp edges. Sufficient clearance is maintained between tire and housing to afford chain clearance under all loads within capacity of bus.

SEATS

Seats provide a minimum seating width of 13 inches per pupil, are forward facing and are placed on 27 inch centers.

Seats are equipped with springs and suitable padding and back rests are suitably padded. Cushions and backs are covered with genuine leather.

A webbed center grab handle is provided on aisle end of seat back.

Seat back is 1¼ inch narrower at the top than at the cushion level thus forming an aisle space of 15 inches at top of seat back.

Longitudinal distance between seat back at seat level is 24 inches.

Side swing driver's seat is adjustable providing a distance of 12 to 16 inches between the seat back and steering wheel. Seat to rear of driver is centered 27 inches when driver is in the back position.

All seats are securely bolted to floor and side wall supports.

FLOOR AND FLOOR COVERING

Subfloor is all metal material with formed floor pan of 14 gauge steel and reinforced with ½ x 2” bar steel providing proper rigidity without the use of outriggers.

Floor pans and reinforcing cross bars are riveted and welded together.

An exterior grade of ½” plywood used as a medium of insulation is placed on top of metal floor.

Armstrong's automat plain linoleum is used under seats and Armstrong's automat ribbed linoleum is used in aisle space and at entrance step.

BODY MOUNTING

Each body is mounted on chassis with at least 2/3 of the body length measured from the front of the dash, forward of the center of the rear axle.

Body is securely bolted to the chassis frame through the medium of ¼” steel frame clip at sufficient intervals preventing weaving, creeping or buckling of body. Frame clips are located on 27 inch centers wherever possible.

AISLES

The main aisle is 12 inches in width at the seat level and 15 inches at the top of the seat back rest.

The aisle width at the emergency door is 12 inches measured between perpendicular in front of the lounge seat and the back of the next forward seat back. The distance from the lounge seat back rest to the perpendicular back of the back rest of the next seat forward is 22 inches, approximately 18 inches off the floor.

Wheelhousing does not extend into the 12 inch emergency aisle as defined in paragraph above.

BODY DIMENSIONS

Body maximum width is 96 inches.

Headroom at the center aisle line is 70 inches.

Maximum overall body height above floor level is 73 inches.
BOOK RACKS

Book racks are provided above the side window from the first cross seat to the back of the second cross seat from the rear.

The left side book rack does not extend over the aisle space leading to the emergency door. Book racks are free from sharp corners or sharp projections and are provided with separators at each body post and longitudinal bumper pad at aisle side.

DOOR

Entrance door is manually controlled of folding leaf type with rubber safety edge on door and body post.

Entrance door fully encloses stepwell and has an opening width of 25 inches at the belt line. Height above floor level is 53 inches.

Emergency door is located at the left rear side of the body, horizontal opening of 28 inches, 18 inches above the floor level and a perpendicular opening of 51 inches.

The emergency door opens outward and is hinged at the front. It is provided with a 3-point locking device operated independently of the driver. Optional—center rear emergency door.

An emergency door switch operates a warning signal located at the instrument panel in front of the driver. This switch operates upon release of the 3-point safety lock.

A sign "Emergency Door" is placed in a horizontal position in letters 1½ inches in height above the emergency door. A red light with a 2 inch lens is placed above the emergency door and is wired with the interior lighting circuit of the body.

WINDOWS

All glass in windows and doors is safety glass of approved make and permanently marked.

All side windows except driver's are of two piece split steel drop sash. The lower section is stationary and is 8 inches in height above window sill, kick-out type.

The window sill is of the slanting type and is completely sealed, eliminating any possible moisture entering space between outer and inner panel.

The upper section of the sash raises and lowers in vertical guide and is controlled by spring type locks at each end corner of sash.

The driver's window is of the regulated type and lowers to the window sill level. It is completely weather stripped and a metal trough is installed below, providing a drain for moisture which may accumulate between body panels.

Rear windows, rear quarter, emergency door and front quarter windows are stationary.

WINDSHIELD

Windshield is a safety plate glass of approved make and is permanently marked.

Windshield is stationary and is provided with dual windshield wipers, 105° arc, 12 inch blade and 10 inch arm.

DEFROSTERS

Two defrosters operate from front heater unit.

Electric fan is mounted at each upper side of the windshield.

HEATING AND VENTILATING

Heaters are of the hot water type and will maintain a 50° temperature inside of the bus with zero degree temperature outside.

All heaters are provided with an outside air intake, located immediately below the belt line.

Body exhaust air outlet is at the front roof line and is of a capacity equal to fresh air intake.

LIGHTING

Interior lights are on a separate circuit and are so located as to illuminate seats and aisles.

Stepwell is equipped with a light operated by entrance door.

Two amber streaming marker lights are located at upper front roof corners and two red streaming marker lights are located at upper rear roof corners.

Dual recessed red stop lights are installed at the belt line in the rear and dual recessed amber stop lights are installed at each side of school bus sign in front. Stop lights are provided with 5 inch diameter lens and are capable of being seen for a distance of 100 yards.
Three amber running lights are installed at the front center roof line and three red running lights are installed at the center rear roof line. A flasher unit is installed in the stop light circuit which also controls these running lights.

Dual rear directional signals as approved by Public Service Commission are installed directly below the rear window.

A rear recessed license plate holder is installed in center of rear compartment door and is illuminated by a tail light.

All wiring is of harness type and all circuits are fused, which are located under the instrument panel in a switch box.

REFLECTORS

Two red "Person's" long reflectors are installed at the rear of bus serving as markers below the belt line for width of bus.

Two amber "Person's" long reflectors are installed at the front of bus serving as markers below the belt line for width of bus.

GUARD RAILS

A guard rail and stanchion is installed to the rear and right of driver.

Guard rail has a clearance of 2 inches from driver's seat when it is in the aft position.

A guard rail, stanchion and guard panel are installed immediately to the rear of entrance stepwell.

STEPWELL

Distance from top of floor to top of stepwell tread plate is 14 inches.

A light located in stepwell is operated by entrance door. Step is fabricated of diamantette tread plate.

A grab handle is installed on inside of rear leaf of entrance door, thus providing a handle on the right of the doorway when entrance door is open.

REAR BUMPER

Rear Bumper is fabricated from heavy gauge steel and is securely bolted to the chassis frame.

Design of rear bumper does not permit space for rider end also includes a bracket supporting the rear end of the exhaust tail pipe.

RUB RAILS

Rub rails are of the applied type, one located at the floor line and one located at the seat cushion level.

Rub rails are rolled steel section.

LETTERING AND PAINTING

Space is provided on side of bus body for name of owner, lessee and/or operator.

Any size lettering or wording as is required on rear and front exterior of bus.

The exterior surface is painted in standard chrome yellow synthetic enamel. Special color combinations are available.

TOOL COMPARTMENT

The rear compartment is located under the rear lounge seat and is accessible from the rear compartment door in the rear.

A tire carrier is provided in this compartment.

ACCESSORIES

Two (2) one quart capacity fire extinguishers of pressure type approved by the Underwriter's Laboratory are mounted in the front of the bus.

A 24 unit type first aid kit in a metal case is mounted in the front of the bus.

An interior rear view mirror non glare type 4 x 15 inches is mounted in front of driver on inside above windshield, giving driver a rear and general interior view of body. An exterior rear view mirror is installed at left front to give driver view of the left rear side of bus.

An adjustable sun visor is located at the front of the driver.

An axe approximately 2 pound head, 18 inch handle is mounted to the left of the driver.

DEPARTMENTAL HURCHING AGENT

School Bus Requirements

There are two schools for which we will require buses to provide transportation for Indian children for September 1, 1947. These two schools are:

1. Kekaskomi Day School
2. Mount Elgin Day School.

1. Kekaskomi Day School

This is a four-room school now being completed on the Kekaskomi Reserve, Cape Breton, N.S. The Indians from the scattered reserves throughout this province are being concentrated on this big reservation where adequate medical care, educational facilities and other social services can be made available.

In line with consolidated school policies of provincial departments of education, a four-room school was erected rather than having four small one-room school houses scattered over the reserve. In this way we will also be able to offer vocational training for both boys and girls—a thing that is impossible in a one-room school.

A 30 passenger bus will be required to transport those children living at a distance greater than 5 miles from the
school. It is estimated there will be some forty odd children so located and that two trips will be necessary.

2. Mt. Elgin Day School

Here we converted an old residential school into a day school. Actually this is a high school, drawing the older pupils from the smaller schools on the reserve. In November, 1946, a Ford 1½ ton ex-army ambulance was purchased as a school bus. This bus has been over-crowded all winter and we have been highly gratified at the pupils' response to the higher education that we are offering.

Actually it has proven very much cheaper to run this as a day school rather than a residential school. However, there will be some 65 pupils in attendance at this school in September and further transportation will have to be provided. At the present time the former ambulance is making 2 trips each morning and each afternoon. The school is being conducted from 8:30 until 5:00 in order to accommodate those children who arrive early and those who arrive later.

This reserve is a very large one and the school is in the centre. With the larger number of students who will pass their entrance in June it will be absolutely essential to provide another bus for them. The former ambulance can then do the loop to the east of the school and the new bus can do the loop to the west of the school.

In both instances, Car Assets Corporation have been written concerning the provision of these busses and they have reported no results in their endeavours to locate suitable vehicles. These letters are attached.

Re: Your File 7-9-5 (WT 1)

Following receipt of your letter of July 10th I made arrangements to visit the garage of the London Bus Company and inspect vehicles they offer for sale.

First, let me explain that these buses have been in service on the streets of London since the old "trolley car" system was discontinued. There are two 23 passenger capacity types and one 32. The 32 is decidedly not suitable for school bus transportation; therefore I think I may dispense with any report on it. The smaller type could perhaps be used satisfactorily, but I am unimpressed with the initial cost of second-hand vehicles with engine trouble to their credit of one third of a million miles - I hesitate. However, since I was asked to examine the buses my report is as follows:

The first point that struck me was the over-all size, in other words too much bus and not enough seating accommodation for school bus service. This, however, is not a major handicap as changes could be made. I was then particularly interested in road clearance which causes problems on most Indian Reservations. We must keep in mind the mud in the late Fall and early Spring and the snow during the Winter, also the fact that we have absolutely no snow removal equipment. This is indeed a problem.

Road clearance is approximately 16 inches which is not bad and, with its weight, would perhaps handle itself. I then suggested that they start the motor and go for a drive. "Sure, why not." On the road the engine seemed to be running smoothly but in high gear I noticed a decided shudder in the rear end. After driving around the town there was some difference of opinion among the bus officials as to whether or not it is characteristic of the gears and whether replacing them would stop it. Apart from this it appeared to be running smoothly, particularly good for entering the easy manoeuvrability of the buses. The interior is in fair condition and the tires are all re-caps. If purchase is made they promise to equip both buses with the best re-caps they have in stock.
I was not too hasty and gave myself ample time to look the job over thoroughly. My final conclusion is that they are rather cumbersome for school bus service but will do the job and perhaps satisfactorily. I must keep in mind, however, their age and the miles travelled. If this were a personal transaction between the Bus Company and myself I would not care to commit myself to $3,550.00 and certainly I would not pay this amount for any second-hand motor vehicle with an engine mileage of 340,000 and 323,000 miles. I feel, if we are going to spend $3,550.00 on a school bus, that we should be looking for a type with less body space, a little more clearance and more seating accommodation. There are many types of small buses that one sees on the road which I am sure, purchased new, would not cost a great deal more, if any, than $3,550.00.

As far as we at the Caradoc Agency are concerned it is not a matter of urgency. We are getting along without major difficulties. I would therefore suggest that we do not commit ourselves too hastily and when we purchase let us decide on something that is standard and serviceable and will give good service for years without major repairs. It is difficult for me to say everything I would like by correspondence. Perhaps in the near future we may get together on this school transportation question. In the meantime if, after reading this report, you feel that there is an immediate use for these buses then either one, or the two, will likely do the jobs you have in mind and perhaps give good service; but you must be prepared, as with any vehicle with the recorded mileages, for major breaks and repairs.

In conclusion say I say that it must go in the records that the need at the Caradoc Agency is not sufficiently pressing to justify my recommending the purchase of either of these buses at the prices quoted.

I have attached, hereto, pictures of the types offered for sale.

Yours truly,

Geo. W. Down,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

September 13, 1947.

Col. F. Noary,
Supt., Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Col. Noary,

In view of your cooperation in the matter of securing teachers and accommodation for them, I am sorry that I find it necessary to write such a lot of complaint as this must be. You have provided us with a splendid group of teachers, and we were able to open all the new schools on schedule. But we have no transportation, without which the rest is likely to be wasted.

The one bus, which should not carry more than twenty, has been away for repairs for these two weeks. I learned today that we need not look for the parts even before two more weeks. Mr. Burch has been driving the old school truck. I wish you could see it now. It is neither safe nor at all suitable, but what could we do? Had the long-promised second bus been here, it could have carried on nicely.

There will be forty pupils from the Oneida side this year, that is to happen when they start. We need that 60-passenger bus now, next Monday. It will be hard indeed to convince you that there are none available, when they have been advertised in our Sunday paper for the past month, even up to yesterday's paper clipped enclosed, one of which I sent earlier. I find it difficult to believe that anyone has even made an attempt to secure such a bus for us. There should be from 60 to 65 pupils this year. The need of a 40-passenger bus has been admitted repeatedly; there has been a fairly wide choice of vehicles available, yet a year has gone by, we begin the third week of school, and there is still no indication of our having such a bus.

I hope there will be an early reply to this letter -- in the form of an advance on service for my trouble.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Reference your 73170-15-11 of September 18 -

It is noted from the attached letter of the Ford Motor Company that they are prepared to provide a 29 passenger school bus for the sum of $6,153.

Muncey, Ontario,
Oct. 27, 1947.

Re: Your File 7-9-5 (WTL)

I regret that I find it necessary to again draw attention to my letter of September 5, 1947, also telephone conversations, with regard to the electrical and heating contracts at the new school under construction at the Caradoc Agency. In this connection I am at the point in construction where electrical roughing in work should be commenced. I am also ready for the heating unit. If you will consult the blue print you will note that the heating is hot air. It therefore means that all shafts leading to the various classrooms must be installed before the partitions are built.

I think I mentioned in my letter the difficulty in securing firms, situated as we are, interested in a job at Muncey. If a decision of some kind is not soon reached as to how I am to proceed with this work I shall have to call a halt in building operations. I think you will agree and understand my position and realize that there is no point in building only to tear down again. It would therefore be greatly appreciated if you would please endeavour to expedite a decision.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dep't of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

GWD/JA

Ottawa, October 25, 1947.

The Deputy Minister,

Dear Sir,-

The Committee have for consideration applications for the purchase of two school busses for the Indian Affairs Branch, one for use at Muncey, Ontario, and the other for use at Eskasoni, N.S.

As these are expensive vehicles and as the providing of transportation for Indian children to and from school appears to be a departure from the usual practice, the Committee would appreciate receiving additional information in this regard before passing upon the recommendations:

(a) How many busses does the department expect to purchase for the purpose of transporting Indian children to and from school.

(b) Where will they be located.

(c) Approximately how many children will be carried at each centre.

(d) How many round trips per day per vehicle.

(e) What is the minimum and maximum distances from homes to school at each centre.

(f) How do the children get to school presently at each centre.

(g) Under what authority is transportation by Government vehicles provided.

Yours very truly,

Ottawa, November 14, 1947.

Memorandum

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENDA

School Buses for Caradoc and Eskasoni Indian Day Schools

Reference your 73169-15-11
73170-15-11 of October 28th.

The answers to the questions raised by the Government Motor Vehicle Committee, concerning the purchase of these two buses are as follows:

(1) Q. How many buses does the Department expect to purchase for the purpose of transporting Indian children to and from school?

A. This will depend upon the recommendations of the Parliamentary Committee into the Indian Act. At the present time indications are that they will favour the operation of day schools over residential schools. If this is the case then it will become the gradual policy of the Department to reduce the number of residential schools and to operate day schools in their places. These consolidated day schools will require buses to carry the children daily to school.

(2) Q. Where will they be located?

A. At the present time there are only four centres at which we feel these will be required. These are, Caradoc, Ontario, Eskasoni, Nova Scotia, Wikwemikong, Ontario and Six Nations, Ontario. At the first two places buses are definitely required at the present time. It is not anticipated that our building plans will have proceeded
far enough at the other two reserves to necessitate the purchase of buses until next year.

(3) C. Approximately how many children will be carried at each centre?

A. At Caradoc there are fifty children and at Eskasoni there are seventy children. At Six Nations and at Wikwemikong, the progress made in our building plans will decide the number who will have to be transported.

(4) C. How many round trips per day per vehicle?

A. At Caradoc there will be two round trips per day as long as the old bus continues to function. In bad weather when we are unable to use the old bus, the new bus will have to do four round trips per day (See attached map).

At Eskasoni there will be two round trips per day.

(5) C. What is the minimum and maximum distances from homes to schools at each centre?

A. Our policy in this regard is to follow the regulations usually followed by Provincial Departments of Education. This is to the effect that children under ten years of age can be expected to walk up to two miles to school and that children over ten years of age can be expected to walk up to three miles.

The maps attached hereto will show clearly the long distances involved in these two places.

(6) C. How do the children get to school presently at each centre?

A. At Caradoc the residential school was closed on the understanding that a day school would be opened and that transportation for these children would be provided as prescribed in the Indian Act. We are unable to get tenders for the provision of a new bus; therefore, we obtained a former army ambulance. We are using this to do one circuit on the Caradoc Reserve and are using an open farm truck on the smaller circuit.
It is our intention to use the new bus on the larger circuit and to use the ambulance bus on the smaller circuit. At the present time we are running grave risks and are endangering the health and safety of these children by transporting them in an open farm truck.

The school block at the former residential school is one hundred years old and has been condemned but we have a new four room school now being rushed to completion. The school population on this Reserve has grown to such an extent that at the present time we are conducting classes in a church basement and in an agricultural hall as well as in the other school buildings previously provided. We can, undoubtedly, fill this new bus to capacity and within a short time have many standees. This new school will also operate as a consolidated high school.

At Eskasoni, the Indian Affairs Branch has been carrying out a large consolidation scheme by moving Indians from isolated reserves of Nova Scotia to a centralized Reserve ideally located at Eskasoni. We have just completed a four room day school and have hired a staff of fully qualified teachers. The enrolment at this school is, at the present time one hundred and twenty and of these some sixty require transportation, (See attached map). We are using our farm truck to transport daily these sixty children back and forth to the school. This truck is an open panel model and we have stationed our Indian policemen on it daily to protect those carried. Here again, we are seriously endangering the health and safety of these children, until we provide them with a closed in vehicle as required by the school laws of every one of the nine provinces.

(7) Q. Under what authority is transportation by Government vehicles provided?

A. Section 9 (3) of the Indian Act reads as follows:
"The Superintendent General (Minister) may provide for the transporting of Indian children to and from a boarding or industrial school to which they are assigned..."

Could we please have returned the Caradoc map attached hereto, as this is an official document required by the Indian Agent concerned.

Director

I have received your letter of November 4th, re electrical and heating contracts at the New School, and although I knew the firm mentioned could not undertake this work the emergency of the matter necessitated immediate contact.

The firm you have chosen is not a contracting one in any sense of the word. It is merely two young men, recently located in the village of Delaware, whose work consists mostly of repairing wells and not too intricate plumbing and electrical repairs. In this connection I have given these two boys all the repair work I possibly could. However I discussed the matter of contracts with them and, without hesitation, they advised that they are definitely not hot air heating mechanics and would not, under any circumstance, accept the job. As far as the electrical work is concerned they would only accept it on a cost plus basis, and would likely have to be paid for their work as the job progressed. This would complicate matters and it is doubtful if they would be able to secure a quota of material to carry on the job without delays. They are not equipped; they are not contractors, not fully qualified and I can only conclude that the person submitting the recommendation has insufficiently estimated the job we have on hand and insufficiently estimated the qualifications of these two young men representing the Delaware Plumbing and Electric Company.

I have received your letter of November 16th with regard to the installing of a furnace at the New School. In this connection Mr. Phil Phelan recently visited the Agency and I discussed with him the possibility of an oil furnace which would be a much more satisfactory unit for this building, and he intimated that he would take the matter up with the Engineering and Surveys Branch on his arrival back in Ottawa; therefore before contacting Mr. Dodds, of Glencoe, Ontario, I would like your views on the matter. It will then enable me to putline to Mr. Dodds the type of furnace required, either coal or oil. If a coal furnace must be installed it will have to be equipped complete with stoker and blower unit and thermostatically controlled. Oil is easier, more economical, and would not require a certified person which I believe, under Provincial law, is necessary in public and school buildings.

However, the suggestion emanated from a discussion between Mr. Phelan and myself. Your decision in the matter will be followed as soon as your wishes are received.

I find it necessary to draw attention to repairs needed for the set 1 bus, Departmental Vehicle No. 1168, and to register protest against the system outlined in paragraph 12, page 6, of the Indian Agent's References and Regulations wherein it advised that tires must not be purchased until Ottawa approval has been obtained. I know, of course, that the ruling is not your making but it does seem strange that such a vital necessity to the running of any vehicle must be held up in such a manner. Please be advised that, owing to a blow out, a complete check was made of all tires, six in number, and they are all in a condition dangerous to safe driving particularly the transportation of school children. The set is the original which came with the truck over a year ago and, as the complete unit is a discarded military ambulance, they have already given very little service. Second hand equipment of any type is more or less trouble equipment and evidently this vehicle is no exception. I can only suggest that if the bus is to remain in service that it be equipped with new tires all around as soon as possible, six in all, complete with tubes. The approximate cost for each tire is $45.40 less 10 per cent less 10 per cent tax = $39.95 for each tire. The approximate total cost is $239.70.

In addition Mr. Earl Burch, the driver, advises that there must be some system of heating the vehicle both in
the driving cab and the bus proper. When this vehicle was received it was stripped of everything apart from necessary running equipment. I would therefore suggest that a universal type of heater be authorized for the driver's cab, also a small motor which, I understand, may be attached to the heating system and drives a fan circulating the heat into the bus proper. I do not know the approximate cost of these units but I would say $100.00 should cover the heating suggestion.

The matter of tires is urgent. I would therefore please request a reply as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

To the Departmental Purchasing Agent, Ottawa, (File 709-5)

PLEASE FURNISH THE FOLLOWING SUPPLIES FOR USE OF

516 ALLOTMENT 12-415 ALLOCATION SYMBOLS

Mr. George W. Down, Indian Agency, Munsey, Ontario.

whilst required

UNIT PRICE TOTAL

6 Tires (20" r Department vehicle No. 3)

Note: In connection with this order, the Agent writes as follows:

"Owing to a blow out a complete check was made of all tires, six in number, and they are all in a condition dangerous to safe driving, particularly the transportation of school children. The bus is the original which came with the truck over a year ago, and as the complete unit is a discarded military ambulance, they have already given many miles of service. If the bus is to remain in service it should be equipped with new tires all round as soon as possible."

This vehicle is being used to transport children to the Cariboo School and in view of the Agent's report we trust that you will arrange the immediate purchase of the tires requested.

I hereby certify that I have personal knowledge that all the above articles are required in the Department and for Departmental purposes only. The expenditure required by this requisition is strictly unavoidable and the public interest will suffer if it is not made.

SIGNED:

APPROVED:

Director

Further reference to the installation of hydro power at the Continuation School now under construction and, in particular, your letter of November 4th.

I have been able to make contact with the Delaware Plumbing and Electric Company and they advise that a tender or contract is out of the question; fluctuation of material prices will not permit safe tenders to be submitted. The firm is, however, prepared to accept the work and proceed immediately on a cost plus basis. I am of the opinion that a cost plus basis is the only way in which we may expect to get the work done.

Please give this matter urgency and, if favourable, I will advise the Delaware Plumbing and Electric to proceed at once.

Yours truly,
